Brexit camp could win if economy remains calm until 2017

David Cameron's strategy for renegotiating the terms of Britain's membership of the EU is becoming increasingly bogged down even without the election of the brilliant Jeremy 'yes or no' Corbyn as Labour leader, or the TUC bringing its criticisms of Europe to a head on Tuesday.
Foreigners have their own characters, such as Corbyn and Nigel Farages.

One European diplomat explained last week that - sunk in similar crises to the one in the EU - not all of them being domestically-triggered - some member states are fuelled with Britain's agenda of concessions and treaty changes, which most do not want.
At its annual meeting in Brighton the TUC decided it did not want this either if it eroded social protection.
We could even call it Dave and George's selfie agenda.

The Prime Minister and Chancellor attend summits or bilateral sessions in foreign capitals, take a photo in front of a famous local monument, with or without the local representative, then return home and declare that they have won allies for reform.
This is only about me.

My European friend, who wants a Britain with an outward-looking outlook under the EU roof - “Don’t leave us alone with France” as Berlin puts it - suggests that several obtuse ministers and officials in certain capitals have now reached the point where they don’t care whether they stay or go.

Angela Merkel, the cautious German chancellor, is an ally but has been in power for 10 years and wants to leave before her position is weakened, as happened to Thatcher (11 years), Mitterrand (14) and Kohl (16) who stayed too long.
In 2017, France's president, Francois Hollande, will be reelected or replaced.
And his power is on the wane.
Poland may soon have a right-wing nationalist government, Spain a left-wing one.

It is hard to believe they will help the posing English, whose energy would be better spent trying to prevent Scotland from leaving the United Kingdom - something they do not want because most of them have similar separatist tendencies.
So ministers may even plan to make deliberately unhelpful remarks in the style of the SNP, in the 2017 UK referendum campaign, to speed up the Brexit process, my friend suggests.
"Renegotiation was fixed" and "Britain did not get anything of value from the renegotiation."

Europeans know first-hand how insatiable Fleet Street can be and how sceptical oligarchic press barons are towards the EU, because they didn't participate in the 1975 referendum inspired by Tony Benn which ratified our 1973 entry by a 2:1 margin.
You may vaguely remember Boris Johnson, the euro-opportunist, who became famous in the early 1990s when he was Brussels correspondent.
Ed Miliband knew his enemies.
They included a mix of tax-dodging bagmen, foreign phone fraudsters and pseudo non-doms who own most of the big newspapers.

Tony Blair actually saw it the same way, but he realized that when you are locked in a cage with an angry gorilla, you have to give him bananas to distract him from the thought of eating you for lunch and again for tea.

Indeed, Miliband was more Blairite than Blair in his opposition to Cameron's referendum idea, given that Blair made a concession on principle with regard to the EU constitution abandoned and buried by French and Dutch voters in 2005, which provided him an exit card.
The press has not forgiven him for that.

But Jeremy Corbyn, who patted me on the back affably on Monday in Westminster – I told him not to waste his time on me – seems in danger of adopting Murdoch's 1980s strategy of boycotting Neil Kinnock, a mistake then and now.
It will take time, but it needs to develop a coherent strategy for engaging with the media, not with me but certainly with Andrew Marr whose position at the BBC became vacant on Sunday.
Corbyn's official position on Europe is what I would charitably call evolving.
He said he wants to remain in a reformed EU.
Most of those who do not agree with the Conservative Anglicism might agree with this.

This is what Hilary “A Benn, but not a Bennite” Benn was saying on radio and TV this week, as the scout within him struggled to admit that Corbyn’s appointment of John McDonnell as shadow chancellor was a bad idea.
It reminded me of the 1970s when his father fought on TV to be disloyal to his labour colleagues without going too far and losing his cabinet post.
Hillary's fight was more attractive.
But the fight to 'remain in any situation' - Benn's phrase - does not tally with what McDonnell has said or what JC told colleagues and MPs in a private meeting on Monday night.

No matter what image Corbyn might be trying to project – and it's had some impact on me too – message discipline remains important in the age of television and particularly in the whirlpool of social media, a hotbed of paranoia and betrayal.
It is right not to give Cameron a free pass in Europe, allowing him to take for granted Labour's support in the referendum campaign, McDonnell said.
Simon Jenkins certainly thinks so.

But McDonnell and Corbyn's basic sophistry on EU membership — in keeping with their anti-capitalist past — is no longer merely an esoteric discussion among left-wing dissidents for whom the narcissism of small differences is a central dogma.
As with his NATO sophistry - Tom Watson is adamant that JC will not campaign for withdrawal - foreign diplomats will be forced to try to understand.
Why should Paris or Berlin waste political capital - and there are suspicious voters there - on concessions to Britain when it might all be for nothing?

The US is already quite disappointed with Britain's poor military performance in Iraq, Libya and Syria, even with a Conservative government cutting costs, as I was reminded at the launch of the British Influence Security Forum on Monday.
Experts criticize UK Public Health department's decision on e-cigarettes

According to researchers, a government agency's claim that e-cigarettes are 95 percent less harmful than smoking was the result of a meeting involving 12 people, some with ties to the tobacco industry.
Experts from the editorial board of the British Medical Journal (BMJ) have joined The Lancet in criticising the evidence used by Public Health England (PHE) in its report on e-cigarettes.
PHE published the “reference report” last month and described it as a “comprehensive analysis of the evidence.”
Some researchers, however, have questioned the robustness of the data and pointed to ties between some experts and the tobacco industry.
A paper published last month in the medical journal Lancet criticized the “extraordinarily flimsy basis” on which PHE had based its key conclusion.
Two other researchers writing in the BMJ have questioned the veracity and underlying evidence of the findings "on firm ground or shifting sand."

Martin McKee, professor of European public health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and Simon Capewell, professor of clinical epidemiology at Liverpool University, said: "A fundamental principle of public health is that policies should be based on evidence of effectiveness."
They said they expected PHE's assertion that "current estimates suggest e-cigarettes are around 95% less harmful than smoking" to be based on a detailed analysis of the evidence and models.

In fact, a single meeting attended by 12 people led to the development of a multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) model that synthesized their views on the negative effects associated with different nicotine-containing products; the results of this meeting were briefly reported in a research paper.

McKee and Capewell said one of the meeting's sponsors was a company called EuroSwiss Health, whose executive director was said to have received past funding from British American Tobacco for an independent study.
He also validated BAT's accreditation in public health in a sustainability report, he said.

They added that one of the 12 participants in the meeting disclosed funding received from an e-cigarette manufacturer, but not the funding reportedly received from tobacco and cigarette company Philip Morris International.
No reasons have been given for the selection of panel members, but among those listed are a number of prominent e-cigarette industry players, some of whom are on record as receiving industry funding.
Other participants at the meeting are not known for their expertise in tobacco control.
The meeting was also attended by the Head of the Tobacco Control Section of PHE.
The research paper “convincingly obfuscates the lack of solid evidence on the harm caused by most products according to most criteria,” McKee and Capewell wrote.
However, the PHE report does not mention any of these links or limitations.
McKee and Capewell said PHE's claim that "to date, there is no evidence that e-cigarettes are acting as a route into smoking for children or non-smokers" is premature.
Professor Kevin Fenton, PHE's Director of Health and Wellbeing, said that the BMJ had responded to previous claims.
He said: "E-cigarettes are significantly less harmful than smoking"
One out of two lifelong smokers dies from the habit.
All the evidence suggests the health risks from e-cigarettes are small compared to the risks of tobacco smoking, but we need to continue to study the long-term effects.
PHE has a clear duty to inform the public of what the evidence does and does not say, especially given the high level of public confusion about the relative risks compared to smoking.
Around 80,000 people die annually from smoking-related diseases and the annual cost to the NHS from smoking is estimated at £2bn.
By clearly stating the current evidence - that while e-cigarettes are not without risk, they carry only a fraction of the harm of smoking - we are doing our national duty.

Ads Shame Britain's Arms Trade

London's transport authority is not amused by this "vandalism" in the form of fliers.
One of the parody announcements produced by the Special Patrol Group.

Many artists are turning to collaboration with activists in protest movements, realizing that they have to get out into the real world for their art to have an impact on society.
Another poster against the arms trade that is seen by passengers riding the subway.
The film has been viewed more than 100,000 times on Facebook in 24 hours and was created by ad agency VCCP who worked pro bono, with the graphic designer and voice artist also working for free.

VCCP creative director Matt Lever was shocked by the silence surrounding the arms fair - with a blank space in the ExCel calendar - and thought: "Let's give them the campaign they're trying to avoid."
They played with the idea of a more realistic commercial but decided that “by adding animation and bright colors, it would be more impactful.”
“They have done a great job helping us raise awareness of the illegal trade in torture equipment at the fair,” said Tom Davies on behalf of Amnesty.
Now it's up to British authorities to take action and ensure that torture equipment is not sold illegally and delivered to the door.
The most creative art on the arms fair theme may be found inside the ExCeL, where exhibitors offer products with fantastic euphemisms.
In a press release, Saab disclosed an order received from the U.S. Army for “AT4CS RS with Shoulder-Supported Launcher.”
It includes "a unique shaped charge that delivers stunning effects behind the armor, inside the target."
Whatever it means, it won't be pleasant.
Eight golden rules for living in a dorm

It's been 11 years since I moved into my dorm, when I was a 19-year-old who still believed in berets and moral relativism, yet it's only now that I remember the forced smiles of those I annoyed and the numerous complaints about others.
Most of what I have learned can be summed up in eight simple rules.
Moving into a dorm can bring on a range of emotions, from nervousness to fear.

The small talk is tempting: to tell people where you're from, whether and where you've spent a gap year, what you think of Corbyn and that 'to be honest, you don't really care about Marmite because, for real guys, it's just yeast extract HAHAHA I'll be in my room.'
Take a deep breath.
And help others to breathe - ask questions and show interest.
They spark conversation and help you distinguish the people you like from those you wouldn't talk to if the flood came and they were the only ones with boats.
Don't suffocate people.
Dorm rooms often abound with drinking parties, movie nights and social gatherings, but they are also the place where people get dressed and try on their underwear.
Related topics: Don’t even think about starting college in a relationship
Introverts get special treatment at university.
Your dorm room should be a refuge, but in many dorms a culture of room-hopping is built on friendship, socialization and lifelong friendships.
All of this can be horrible for someone trying to recharge their batteries.
Nothing in this culture allows you to say “I like you and I want to be friends, but I want you to leave so I can recover the energy I have spent interacting with you.”
Try to notice when a colleague is overwhelmed by socializing - and try sending a text instead of knocking on the door.
Speaking of knocking on doors: do it.
A guy who lived in my dorm had a policy that if a door wasn't locked, he was invited to enter.
He has seen a lot.
Make friends by cooking.

Starting university in Bake-Off fever, if you knock on someone's door to introduce yourself and you take a plate of brownies, it seems less weird, less like the 1950s, "Welcome to the neighborhood, I baked you something, now smile while I ask personal questions."
Homemade treats are a great way to make friends.
Your roommates will feel obliged to talk and could end up associating your face with a tasty surprise.
Of course, you have to be a good cook.
The flour, sugar, and fat concoction will probably make the others pretend to be asleep when you knock on the door.
Food theft is a common crime in student dormitories.
If you steal someone's egg, it's theft, but if you take a drop of milk to put in your tea, it's still theft?
Ask the owner.
He will probably tell you to serve it even if it is boiling inside.
If someone steals your things, it sucks, and I get it - try to approach the issue more maturely than my roommate, who dyed his milk with liquid detergent in order to punish those who stole it.
He is currently in prison.
Don't make noise that doesn't allow others to sleep or study.
Not just because it makes sense, but because you literally go on broken glass.
A girl from upstairs asked her neighbor to turn down the music because it was 3 AM and she had an exam in the morning.
Their reaction was to turn the music louder.
When the music finally ended at 5 a.m., the girl was nice enough to let them sleep for two hours before cranking up the music again and locking the door, leaving for a three-hour exam.
Wouldn't it be romantic if your future husband/wife moved onto the same floor?

On the other hand, wouldn't it be weird if you confused a neighbor with your future husband, you got involved and then broke up and you had to see him every day and maybe even see him take over all your common friends?
Of course, you can't fight your heart - but if your sexy neighbor is definitely not your future husband, at least try and be rational.
The line between a prank and a threat is thinner than it seems in the moment when you realize someone has left their keys in an unlocked room.
A successful prank is amusing, but it can turn nasty in a matter of minutes.
Teach a fun and valuable lesson on safety by hiding something - but never mess up someone's room with toothpaste and shampoo.
Lock the door and put the keys in a glass of water that you place in the freezer - but don't tape someone's belongings to the ceiling more than twice.
Violinist David Grimal: In Bach's Time, There Were No World Tours
Beethoven, Brahms, Bartok, Enescu were working people, artists and not commercial representatives.

French violinist David Grimal is considered one of the great artists of our time, known not only as a soloist but also as the initiator of a somewhat unusual, even "strange" project, as he himself defines it: Les Dissonances - an orchestra made up of international soloists and talented musicians, which interprets a symphonic repertoire without having a conductor, which makes it at least a curiosity in the classical music landscape.

Les Dissonances was at the Enescu Festival this year with two shows: one on Sunday with David Grimal, the orchestra's founder, as the soloist, and one on Monday with cellist Xavier Phillips in the lead, with works by Enescu included.
Both shows, staged at the Athenaeum stage, showed the public a different way to interpret classical music.
Les Dissonances first appeared on the musical scene in 2004 as the only classical musical ensemble without a conductor.
The conductor is the most important musician for the musicians.
It is true, on the one hand musicians need education either to become soloists or to become performers in an orchestra - I'm talking about instrumentalists, not composers.
They are trained as "skilled workers".
They themselves have the impression that they need a conductor.
On the other side of the scene, for the audience, all of the musical fetishization is centered around the conductor.
Thus, the business, the music industry, does its marketing.
So we're not talking about music anymore.
"So if you look at this world, you have on the one hand skilled workers, which is stupid, and you have an audience who can't listen but has to look, which is also stupid," David Grimal says.
The violinist says this change in the way that he makes music came about as a result of "musical disappointments" in his solo career.
I was like a high-level athlete who had to do the same exercise all over the world with different orchestras to make lots of money and bring money to the music industry.
When I was around 30 years old, about 10 years ago, I found this to be very depressing because I could no longer find the creativity and human fraternity in this system.
So I found no sense in continuing on this path.
That is why I decided to create Les Dissonances.
This happened in 2004, and at that time nobody did such a thing without a conductor: "The musical world, extremely conservative, did not want such projects".
"How do you imagine doing marketing with a collective of musicians in which there is no ego?" the artist asks.
David Grimal admits that Les Dissonances is a “luxury”, clarifying that none of the musicians who form part of the orchestra depends on the success of this project to survive.

In the 10 years of its existence, the group's lack of a conductor has not proven a hindrance to the musical act: "Oddly enough, the more complex the repertoire, the easier it seems, because all the musicians are forced to be present in the opera, and not just in their role," Grimal said, adding that in Sunday's show, "we were 74 conductors on the stage."

In Grimal's opinion, the Enescu Festival is a "very brave" festival for inviting Les Dissonances: "An extraordinary festival, where the greatest orchestras in the world play 3 times a day, and in the midst of these orchestras you invited this strange group".
In a temple of orchestral tradition such as the Enescu Festival, there is room and interest for something different, something that breaks barriers.

Speaking about Enescu's work, the violinist acknowledges that he feels the Romanianness of the famous Romanian composer's music, so he didn't need a special approach when introducing Enescu's works in his repertoire.
Grimal writes that Enescu's music is very instinctive, but that happens when we talk about George Enescu and Romanian music, "because there is also a George Enescu who made French music."
Grimal advocates changing the way classical musical education is done, saying "the musical profession, as it is organized today, has a whiff of death" and that "the future of music is music itself."
We don't need to go on a world tour 5 times a year if it doesn't really serve any purpose.
In Bach's time there were no world tours.
Beethoven, Brahms, Bartok, Enescu were people who worked, who were artists, not commercial representatives.
For me, organizing concerts, festivals, tours, album launches, all of this is wonderful, extraordinary, provided it is done in the service of music.
If not, we're in a system where creativity suffers, it no longer has freedom.

To illustrate this phenomenon, David Grimal gave the example of Romanian products before and after accession to the European Union: "In Romania, before entering the EU, you had good vegetables and meat."
To enter the EU you had to adopt health laws that are not good for vegetables and meat.
Production and agriculture are at the service of the supermarkets, just like in France.
The same thing happens with music. It's the same logic.
Les Dissonances make reds that are not very pretty, but when you cut them, they are real reds.

In an ideal world, music should come back to the center and the institutions and industries that manage the system should understand that music does not need to be sold, it needs to be shared and this can be done starting with the educational policy.

"If we were to consider - as the Koreans, the Chinese, or the Japanese do - that Western music is one of the most beautiful things in humanity, we would reintroduce its learning in school, we would reintroduce concerts on TV and through this education we would no longer need to sell musical sub-products", Grimal believes.
There are definitely things in classical music education that remain very communist, that's everywhere, it's very militarized.
It depends on this discipline whether we compare a musician with a soldier, or whether we form a musician who will play an instrument, being, above all, a musician.
We are talking about a completely different education, because if we want to train a soldier that kind of education must be one way, and if we want to train a musician it is completely different.
"In your opinion, what is more dangerous, a soldier or a musician?" asks the French artist with a smile.

Grimal explains that for artists, the reward for another way of making music comes from overcoming this "soldier" status, overcoming what "they believe are their limits": "Musicians discover at a certain moment that they are not soldiers, and that is why they come out smiling after the concert".

David Grimal talked about his musical project and his vision of music and the artist during the "Festival of Ideas", a public discussion organized within the International George Enescu Festival by the Aspen Institute Romania.
David Grimal profile

After studying at the Conservatoire National Superieur de Musique in Paris under Regis Pasquier, a period during which he received guidance and encouragement from such famous artists as Schlomo Mintz and Isaac Stern, David Grimal spent a year studying at the Ecole des Science Politiques in Paris before meeting Philippe Hirshhorn, who changed the course of his life.

David Grimal has an international soloist career, during which he has regularly performed concerts for the past 20 years on the world's main classical music scenes and with prestigious orchestras such as the Orchestre de Paris, Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France, Russian National Orchestra, Orchestre National de Lyon, Chamber Orchestra of Europe, Berliner Symphoniker, New Japan Philharmonic, Orchestre de l'Opera de Lyon, Mozarteum Orchestra Salzburg, Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra and Sinfonia Varsovia, conducted by conductors such as Christoph Eschenbach, Michel Plasson, Michael Schￃnwandt, Peter Csaba, Heinrich Schiff, Lawrence Foster, Emmanuel Krivine, Mikhail Pletnev, Rafael Fruￌhbeck de Burgos and Peter Eotvos, Andris Nelsons, Christian Arming.

He has been the recipient of works dedicated to him by such composers as Marc-Andre Dalbavie, Brice Pauset, Thierry Escaich, Jean-Francois Zygel, Alexander Gasparov, Victor Kissine, Fuminori Tanada, Richard Dubugnon, Ivan Fedele, Philippe Harrowing, Anders Hillborg, Oscar Bianchi, Guillaume Connesson and Frederic Verrieres.
In addition to his solo career, David Grimal has explored personal projects.
The freedom offered by his collaboration with Les Dissonances allowed him to develop his inner universe by exploring repertoires that are not accessible to solo artists.
Alongside Les Dissonances, he founded "L'Autre Saison", a series of concerts given for and with homeless people at the Saint-Leu church, in the heart of Paris.
Since 2008, David Grimal has been the Artist in Residence at the Dijon Opera.
He teaches violin at the Musikhochschule in Saarbrücken, Germany.
He also gives master classes and was a member of the jury of the International Long-Thibaud Competition in Paris in 2010.
He was awarded the Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres by the French Minister of Culture in 2008.
David Grimal plays a Stradivarius, "ex Roederer" from 1710, as well as "Don Quijote", a violin designed for him by the French luthier Jacques Fustier.
David Grimal was present on Sunday at this year's George Enescu International Festival along with the Les Dissonances orchestra, with a program including Debussy, Enescu and Beethoven.
Les Dissonances took the stage again on Monday, this time with cellist Xavier Phillips in the spotlight, and the program featured works by Schnittke, Enescu and Brahms.
Cinema City is looking for "Big Little Voices"
Cinema City launches the coolest challenge for kids: dubbing two characters from the super production "Snow Queen 3D"
Do you have a super talented and spontaneous child who likes movies?
Give him a chance to become a star.

In September, as part of its latest campaign for enthusiastic, ambitious children between the ages of 8 to 16, who want to become future stars, Cinema City is looking for "Little Big Voices," offering them the extraordinary opportunity to dub two characters from a famous animated film.

Whereas in the classic cartoons, the voice of the animated character was given great importance, in recent times, the creation of a story also takes into consideration the people who are going to interpret the voices, and they are usually very well-known actors.
Cinema City Romania wants to discover new voices and that is why we are launching a unique campaign.
We want to find the right voice and we challenge parents to enter their children in our competition.
They will have a special experience, because the characters are nice and the lines are funny.
"The kids will have fun and have a real chance of becoming part of an acting team," said Ioana Ionescu, Marketing Manager at Cinema City Romania.

In the first stage of the competition, from September 11 to September 30, Cinema City will hold a pre-selection, after which 10 children (five girls and five boys) will be chosen, who will be given the opportunity to audition in a recording studio alongside professionals.
All parents have to do is to access the micilevocimari.cinema-city.ro platform, where they can sign up their child for the competition, and prepare them for the voice test.
Next, they must select one of the four movies available on the platform, download the texts that the child will read and then the child will record his or her own dubbing version.

Four films about friendship, fairy-tale heroes, magic and hope can choose contestants for the support test: "Pene Galbene 3D", "Mune - Guardian of the Moon 3D", "Blinky Bill: Koala cel poznaș 3D" and "Albinuța Maya 3D".

In the end, the two most talented children (one boy and one girl) will see their dream come true and will dub a character in the super production "The Snow Queen - Crăiasa Zăpezii 3D", which will be released in Romania in November this year.
FedEx Earnings Mixed, Cuts Fiscal 2016 Forecast

FedEx Corp. reported disappointing results for its latest quarter, as the shipping giant cut its profit outlook for the year because of weak demand for shipping services and higher costs for its ground delivery business.
The company also said it plans to hire about 55,000 seasonal workers for the holiday period.
Last year, FedEx announced they would hire 50,000 seasonal workers for the holiday period.
The company's shares fell about 2.5% in pre-market trading, about 45 minutes before Wednesday's opening bell.
FedEx Corp said it expects to earn between $10.40 and $10.90 a share for the fiscal year ending next May, down 20 cents from its earlier forecast.
Analysts had forecast a figure of $10.84, according to a FactSet poll.

The downward forecast comes despite a 4.9% average price increase that went into effect on January 4, and higher surcharges for ground shipments of large or heavy packages, which will take effect in November.
The company said it still expects an increase in earnings compared to the previous year as a result of cost reductions, higher revenues and the development of online trade.
Chairman and Chief Executive Fred Smith said "the company is facing a substantially weaker global economic environment than we anticipated, particularly in production and international trade."
The hiring plans were announced a day after competitor UPS said it plans to hire 90,000-95,000 seasonal workers, about the same number it hired last year.
In the quarter ended August 31, FedEx earned $692 million, up 6% from a year earlier.
Earnings per share were $2.42, falling below the average estimate of $2.44 per share from 12 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
Profit rose 5% to $12.3 billion.
Six analysts who participated in the Zacks survey expected $12.23 billion.
FedEx has been hit in recent years by a decline in international priority shipping, which has led to stagnant revenues at its Express unit.
But a boom in online shopping boosted FedEx Ground's results.
In the last quarter, ground division revenue increased 29% but operating income was virtually flat due to higher costs for large packages and self-insurance.
The express unit recorded an increase in revenues due to higher base rates, while revenue at the freight division fell due to rising costs.
In pre-market trading, about an hour before opening bell, FedEx shares fell $3.85, or 2.5%, to $150.15.
They fell 11% this year and 17% from a record high reached on June 11.

In the most anticipated meeting in years, Federal Reserve policymakers will spend two days this week around a 27-foot Honduran mahogany table to decide whether it is time to raise a key interest rate for the first time in nearly a decade.
Above them, at one end of the Central Bank meeting room, will loom a mural painting depicting the United States.
The map is intended to remind Janet L. Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, and her colleagues that they must put the nation’s economic interests above all else.
The Federal Reserve has a dual mandate from Congress: to maximize employment in the United States and maintain price stability.
But since the great recession, Fed leaders have acknowledged that there is a third, unwritten mandate: financial stability.

And that third factor could be the X-factor in a decision that's too close to call right now and will likely determine whether the U.S. economy is ready to be weaned off the unprecedented stimulus provided by the near zero short term interest rates that have been in effect since the end of 2008.

Even though most data suggest a strong growing economy, the recent turmoil in global financial markets may worry Fed officials already wary about adding volatility by raising the federal funds rate - even by just a quarter of a percentage point.
"Clearly the labor market and inflation will be the first and foremost things they will look at," said Lindsey M. Piegza, chief economist at brokerage firm Stifel Nicolaus & Co.
"But I think if they were looking for an excuse to not raise rates, the increasing uncertainty in global markets is enough to provide them an excuse to wait," she said.
There is no consensus about the decision Fed will take and this itself is causing instability in the financial markets.
About half of the economists surveyed by Bloomberg recently had anticipated a rate increase this week.
But financial markets are expecting the Fed to hold off, with a key indicator showing the probability of a rate hike at only 30%.
That would signal a stock-market drop if the Fed raises rates, unless policymakers soften the blow by promising it will be a long time before the next increase.
On Tuesday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 228.89 points, or 1.4%, to 16,599.85.
The surge was fueled by expectations that Fed policymakers will keep interest rates steady this week, said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Capital Markets Research Group.
It would be surprising if the Fed raised rates at this point, Lonski said.
If Fed policymakers do this, “they would need to act in depth in their policies to avoid panic in financial markets.”
Other experts said a rate rise would calm financial markets because it would remove uncertainty about when the Fed would act.
Just a month ago, the Fed seemed poised to raise rates by 0.25% this month, the first small step toward a slow tightening of monetary conditions that would confirm the strength of the U.S. recovery.
Yellen said in the spring and early summer that she expected a rate increase this year despite the objections of liberals that more economic progress was needed.
While job creation slowed in August, the labor market has experienced solid growth this year.
The unemployment rate fell to 5.1% last month, the lowest rate in more than seven years and close to the level the Fed considers full employment.
Wage earnings showed signs of growth.
And although inflation continued to fall short of the central bank's annual target, Fed policymakers said that a key reason was the temporary effect of sharply lower oil prices.
“The economy can handle higher rates and needs them given the tightness of the labor market,” said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics.
But global financial markets started to go into a tailspin at the end of this month, after China devalued its currency.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 16% from its May record high as investors worried that a slowing Chinese economy would drag down global growth.
Stocks have fallen back somewhat this month, with the Dow index now about 10% below its May peak.
For Fed policymakers, market turmoil adds to the complex calculus of when to raise rates.

'Without what's happened in the financial markets and the news about the weakening Chinese economy in recent weeks, they'd be more firm in their meeting,' said Stephen D. Oliner, an experienced researcher at UCLA's Ziman Center for Real Estate and a former Fed official.
Now, he predicts they will wait at least a month to better manage the effects.
"There's a lot of uncertainty as to what the impact on the U.S. economy will be and there's almost no data to go on subsequent to the events in China," said Oliner.
Global economic well-being is not one of the Fed's major interests, so it should not really be taken into consideration when taking decisions.
But in reality, the Fed has become the world's monetary authority.
Over recent years, the central bank's influence has been huge.
A mere hint in 2013 by then-Fed Chairman Ben S. Bernanke that the Fed might “taper” its monetary expansion triggered a worldwide market quake.

In a world where markets and economies are increasingly intertwined, it is expected that Fed officials will not only monitor progress in other areas, but will also consult with other central banks and experts to better interpret the global economy.
His decision making process is "more art than science," said Zachary Karabell, head of global strategy at wealth management firm Envestnet Inc.

Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., said this month that "the Fed has a history of overreacting to changes in financial markets that don't seem to have much bearing on the underlying economy."
Lacker, a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets interest rates, cited decisions made in 1998-99.

A financial crisis that struck Asia prompted the Fed to cut its benchmark rate by 0.75 percentage point in three meetings, “despite limited evidence of the implications for US developments, ” Lacker said.
A year later, the Fed officials reversed those cuts.

The Fed should put financial stability at the top of its agenda only in case of a major crisis, such as the 2008 market quake, said Adam S. Posen, a former member of the Bank of England's rate-setting committee.
The recent turmoil is nowhere near that level, he said.
"We certainly don't want to get into a situation where we fear a rise in interest rates because the markets are upset," said Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
The Federal Reserve Act still has a dual mandate and doesn't mention financial stability, and until something changes, I don't think they should take premature action.
Looking for an amazing Thai market?
Try LAX-C in Chinatown.
Yes, Chinatown
The open-air market, which opened in 1997, is owned by LAX-C Inc.
Often called Thai Costco, LAX-C is a Thai wholesale market that also sells to the public.
Yes, it's in Chinatown and not in Thai Town.
The market/depot is a full-service store offering an amazing range of fresh, frozen and dried products, popular Thai and Asian snacks and kitchenware, furniture, religious and holiday decorations.
There is also an auto parts district if you need to buy some motor oil.
The store is huge and it takes at least an hour to go through all the aisles.
If you get hungry from all the shopping, eat at LAX-C BBQ Express.
The store's interior food court (good, reasonably priced) is close to home, and offers more options for take-out meals.
What's in stock: You need something - anything - Thai?
You can probably find it at LAX-C.
The products have reasonable prices, and some items are sold wholesale.
Fresh produce include herbs, fruits and other Asian and Thai products.
The meat section is huge, and so is the fish section - the serving staff will clean and fillet the fish and even fry it for you if you wish.

A large part of the shop is dedicated to the huge freezer section, where you will find frozen curry leaves, melon and ginger, whole ducks, fish, blood and ox balls, pig carcases, fish balls, traditional sausages, semi-prepared meals and many more.
Who buys from there: Restaurant owners and chefs, also families and individuals.
The wide aisles can accommodate both shopping carts and forklifts.
Discovery: Fresh Durian fruits just next to the residential area.
The store is located in an industrial section of Los Angeles on the outskirts of Chinatown and Downtown - just a few blocks from Philippe The Original.
Parking: LAX-C has its own shared parking area with other stores and restaurants.
Although there is a chance that the store will be crowded, it is usually not hard to find a parking spot.

Four people were killed after police fired rubber bullets at protesters in Nepal

Four people, including a 4-year old boy, were killed in southern Nepal after police fired rubber bullets at a crowd protesting against the country's proposed new constitution, an official said Wednesday.
The violence took place Tuesday night in the Rupandehi district, about 280 kilometers west of the capital Kathmandu.
According to Bishnu Prasad Dhakal, the district police chief, more than 1,000 protesters gathered outside a police station and some of them threw stones and Molotov cocktails.
Mr. Dhakal said police forces used tear gas and fired warning shots before resorting to using rubber bullets.
He said that 20 police officers and five civilians were injured.
It was not immediately clear why rubber bullets, which are known to be deadly but are typically used as a less lethal alternative, caused so many deaths.

The clash was the latest incident in weeks of violent protests in Nepal's southern region, where members of the Madhesi ethnic group say the new provinces created under the new constitution would dilute their political influence.
Protests have also been held in western Nepal, where the Tharu ethnic group is demanding its own state.
At least 40 people, including 11 police officers, were killed in the violent clashes that broke out on August 10.

when four major political parties signed an agreement to split the country into provinces - a major step toward a new constitution but an extremely controversial issue in Nepal, a country that has been ruled centrally for hundreds of years.
The process of drafting a new constitution was launched in 2008, but lawmakers accelerated the process after a devastating earthquake killed thousands of people in April.
Nepal's lawmakers this week voted on the draft constitution's provisions and officials said the new charter could be adopted on Sunday.

Romania does not agree and will not apply antidemocratic measures, guard dogs, barbed wire fences or policemen with guns.

NHC says 60 percent chance of cyclone south of Cape Verde Islands

A broad low pressure area located about 560 kilometers south of the southernmost Cape Verde Islands has a 60 percent chance of becoming a tropical cyclone during the next 48 hours, the US National Hurricane Center said on Tuesday.

A well-defined low pressure area located nearly halfway between the Cape Verde Islands and Lesser Antilles also has a 60% chance of becoming a tropical cyclone in the next two days, the Miami-based forecaster added.
Weight-loss surgery may be useful for diabetics with mild obesity
The benefits of weight loss surgery for people with mild obesity and type 2 diabetes may be sustained for at least five years, according to a new study.
It is too early to say whether diabetics with mild obesity live longer after weight-loss surgery than those who follow non-surgical treatments.
“It takes a long time to centralize the data on mortality,” said Dr. Robin Blackstone, a bariatric surgeon who wrote an article about the new study in JAMA Surgery.
Weight-loss operations, also known as bariatric surgery, use various methods to shrink the stomach.
They reduce the feeling of hunger and limit the body's ability to absorb food.

Over the years, bariatric surgery has proven to be effective in treating type 2 diabetes, but most studies have been conducted on individuals with morbid obesity, with a body mass index (BMI) of 35 or higher.
BMI, a measure of weight relative to height, is considered normal in the range of 18.5-24.9.
A BMI of at least 25 indicates that a person is overweight and people with a BMI of over 30 are considered obese.
You can calculate your BMI here: 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv.

For the new study, researchers from the Min-Sheng General Hospital in Taiwan used data gathered after 2007 in a trial that compared two types of bariatric surgery - gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy - in the medical treatment of type 2 diabetes in people with mild obesity.
The average BMI among the patients who underwent surgery fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year of the study.
In the meantime, the percentage of people who received non-surgical treatments for diabetes remained about the same, at 29.
Of those who underwent surgery, diabetes was completely cured in 36 percent of patients and partially cured in 28 percent.
In the medically treated group, by comparison, diabetes was completely cured in just 1 percent and partially cured in only 2 percent of subjects.
In addition, blood pressure control, triglycerides, and "bad" LDL cholesterol "were generally better in the surgery group," the authors concluded.
Researchers also monitored the levels of hemoglobin A1c, which reflects the average blood glucose levels over time.
Researchers write that the optimal level for hemoglobin A1c is under 7%.
After surgery, the average hemoglobin A1c levels dropped from about 9% to about 6%.
But in the group treated with medical methods, the rate remained about 8%.
But this improved "glycemic control" - reflected by improved hemoglobin A1c levels - did not reduce the five-year mortality rate, lead researcher Dr. Chih-Cheng Hsu and colleagues found.
The research team also compared the average outcomes associated with the two types of surgical intervention.

At 5 years, compared with the sleeve gastrectomy group, the bypass group had lost more weight (18.7 vs 14.2 kg), had greater reductions in BMI (7.4 vs 5.1) and hemoglobin A1c (3.1% vs 2.1%), and had a higher probability of complete remission of diabetes (46.9% vs 16.7%).

Although the new study did not show a benefit in survival or surgery after five years, there is evidence from a study of Swedish obese people that surgical intervention prolongs life, Blackstone, from the University of Arizona College of Medicine in Phoenix, said.
In the Swedish study, obese people who underwent bariatric surgery had about a 29 percent lower risk of dying after 15 years, compared with a group that tried more conventional methods.

Although the new study did not show a benefit in survival for patients who had surgery, Blackstone said it is an encouraging finding for people with a BMI under 35 who are interested in the procedure.
“This is the point where this work is critical because it says this surgical intervention is safe in the lower BMI group” without increasing the risk of death or kidney disease, she says.
Blackstone added that patients and their doctors should begin taking weight seriously when a patient's body mass index hits 27 to 30.
“I think we wait too long to encourage people to take this seriously,” she said.
I think once they accumulated these genetic changes that short-circuited their bodies and made them predisposed to obesity and diabetes, it's extremely hard to go back to normal.
“It is impossible for everyone to come to Europe” - Dalai Lama - RT news
Europe cannot take in all refugees, the Dalai Lama said, adding that the real solution to the current refugee crisis lies in the Middle East.
The Tibetan Buddhist leader has issued an appeal for an end to violence in the home countries of refugees.

The Dalai Lama spoke about the current refugee crisis during a speech at the opening of the Dalai Lama Center for Compassion in Oxford, dedicated to ethics studies, at the start of his 10-day visit to Britain.
He said that in the present situation, the interests of humanity should prevail over the interests of each nation and even each continent.
He also pointed out that, while admirable, the response of Western European countries to the refugee crisis is inadequate.
“It is impossible for everybody to come to Europe,” he said in his speech.
While the Dalai Lama praised Germany and Austria's efforts to deal with the crisis, he stressed that it is only a temporary solution.

"It is wonderful to take care of a few thousand refugees, but we also need to think of long-term solutions to bring lasting peace and real development, especially through education, to muslim countries," he stressed.
Ultimately, we need to think of ways to reduce crime in their countries.
We need to reduce the use of force.
"Force has never solved these problems," he added.

On the issue of violence, the Dalai Lama also commented on George Bush's actions after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, saying that the United States' violent response triggered an uncontrollable chain of events.
After the events of September 11, I sent my condolences in a letter to President Bush and told him to solve this problem without resorting to violence.
"I know his motivation was strong, but he used force and generated unexpected consequences," the Dalai Lama said.
Four-fold rise in the number of children who ingested hand sanitizer in the last four years

According to the Georgia Poison Control Center, poison control centers in the U.S. have reported a nearly 400 percent increase since 2010 in the number of children under the age of 12 who have swallowed hand sanitizer with a high alcohol content.

According to Dr. Gaylord Lopez, director of the Georgia Poison Center, cases of hand sanitizer ingestion among children under 12 reported to poison control centers surged from 3,266 in 2010 to 16,117 in 2014.
“Children have better access to these products and, unfortunately, a percentage of them end up in the emergency room,” Lopez told CNN.
Lopez said that some children intentionally drink the detergent, while others do so in order to impress their friends or respond to challenges on social media.
YouTube videos depict teenagers drinking detergent to create cheap drinks.
It appears the teens mixed the detergent with mouthwash and alcohol to make a stronger drink.
Young children can be attracted by the attractive smell of detergent.
"A child doesn't think this is harmful," Lopez says.
Many of the most appealing types are those that are scented.
Strawberry, grape and orange-scented hand sanitizers are the most attractive to children.
Hand sanitizer contains approximately 45-95% alcohol.
Just a few sips of alcohol can cause poisoning in small children.
"It's very concentrated alcohol," Dr. Stephen Thornton, medical director of the Poison Control Center at University of Kansas Hospital, told Fox 4 in Kansas City.
So we don't leave a glass of whiskey on the table, but people leave these hand sanitizers in accessible places and if children get to them, this is a quick way to consume a lot of alcohol.
Nhaijah Russell, a six-year old girl who recently ingested the equivalent of four squirts of strawberry-flavored hand sanitizer at school, was taken to the emergency room for treatment.

She had a blood alcohol content of .179, more than double the legal threshold for adult intoxication, according to Dr. Chris Ritchey, an emergency room physician who treated her at Gwinnett Medical Center outside Atlanta.
Nhaijah was crying and unable to walk when she arrived at the emergency room.
Doctors monitored her overnight at a separate children's hospital to identify signs of brain injury, because the girl fell and hit her head because of the alcohol, Ritchey said.
“It was scary,” Nhaijah’s mother, Ortoria Scott, told CNN.
It could have been fatal.
Lopez advised parents and teachers to use alcohol-free wet wipes or products and not to leave hand sanitizer within a child's reach.
In addition to alcohol poisoning, some detergents have been associated with deaths.
In 2013, two women in Ontario died after ingesting hand sanitizer that contained an undisclosed toxic ingredient.
Health authorities suspect the product contained methanol, a deadly substance, instead of ethyl alcohol, which was listed as the active ingredient.
Three fourth-graders in northern New York conspired to poison their “mean” teacher by “putting antibacterial products in the classroom,” according to a police report.
The teacher is very allergic to hand sanitizer and has banned it in her classroom.
Police deemed the plan “insignificant” and referred the matter to the school board for disciplinary action.

Because the Rangers aren't there.

Deila promises to change the situation.

Scottish unemployment rate remains unchanged while in Britain it rises
Scottish unemployment rate remains unchanged at 164,000 in the May-July period, while the number of unemployed people in the UK as a whole rose by 10,000 to 1.82 million in the same period.

Why I Am Witnessing an Execution in Oklahoma
Today, barring a last-minute legal intervention, I will watch a man be sentenced to death.
If it happens, and I hope it doesn't, I will stand in the witness room at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary and watch as Richard Glossip is executed by lethal injection.
He asked me to be one of four official witnesses to his death.
The invitation came first in January through his best friend, and although I was shocked, I accepted.
As the day gets nearer, the idea scares me.
So why should I do it?
I agreed because I thought it was a good way to tell the entire story of the death penalty.
It would provide a unique perspective.
It is true that journalists can witness executions in America and, because requests usually exceed the number of available spots, a macabre lottery is held to decide who will be chosen.
Oklahoma has cut the number of press seats from 12 to five.
Those elected will look at the execution with impartiality.
I can't do that.
I would stand beside Richard Glossip's closest friends, and I have developed my own bond with him over the months of phone calls and a two-and-a-half-hour visit.
I like the guy.
We often laugh a lot when we talk.
Prison authorities say I cannot be both a witness and a journalist, so I won't be allowed to have a notebook and pen to record what I see.
I will have to try to remember all the details.
A journalist from Oklahoma accused me on Twitter of compromising my impartiality.
Here is the lesson.
Tell the prisoner's story the way he wants it told, get access.
I complained to her.
He acknowledged that he “could have worded it better” but he still believes they are wrong.
Richard Glossip did not agree with some of the things that I said and wrote.
He doesn't tell me what to write, and I wouldn't do it even if he asked.
I told him he could remove me from the witness list at any time.
But he wants an international report to be written on the subject.
He thinks that if he dies, publicity will help the anti-death-penalty movement.
Kim Bellware, a reporter for the Huffington Post, will be joining me.
If you want to find out more about the case, listen to the series of multimedia files I've made.
I will not go into all the details here.
I can't say with certainty that Richard Glossip is innocent.
His actions after Barry Van Treese's death make him guilty of complicity.
But I think it is very likely he is not guilty of the crime.
I firmly believe there was not enough evidence to justify the death penalty.
I think his execution is wrong.
And I will watch him die from this perspective.
I can't claim to be completely objective.
To do this, you can read articles written by other reporters.
From me you will learn what it is like to watch a man I like die uselessly.
Peter Moody claims stewards tried to spy on him and threatens to withdraw from races

Moody said he had always tried to do his best for the racing industry and was in a difficult position with Lidari's positive cobalt test, for which he had no explanation.
For 18 months, he swallowed his words regarding the spying allegations and didn't want to look “like the fox who couldn't reach the grapes”.
"I didn't intend to say anything about it and I've kept quiet for a long time, but sometimes you reach such a level of frustration that it all comes out at once," Moody said.
It is known that it continued.
Sometimes you react and you have to bear the consequences, and I am going to have to live with what I said.
Tonight I will go home and sleep peacefully.
I want to go there with my head held high, and I want the owners that I work with to see that I'm trying to give them the best.
When they start believing that that's not the case, I have to quit my job as a trainer.
At that point I'll have to think about what to do with my certification.
Earlier, Moody dropped a bombshell in an interview with racing.com by saying the integrity department tried to spy on his stables.

“Eighteen months ago Terry Bailey, Dayle Brown and Dr Brian Stewart were sitting in a room with a man - whose name I would say if I was asked - and offered to employ him at my stable to give information on what was going on there,” Moody told Racing.com.
Of course he regards me as a cheat.
If that is the case, then they should all resign because they were incompetent in trying to catch me.
Robert Roulston, the former president of RVL, David Moodie, the current president of RVL, and Bernard Saundry, the current CEO of RVL, knew it then and know it now.
Should I believe this is something personal?
Is it necessary for RVL to start having a backbone and hold people outside the trainers accountable for what happens in the industry?
Do I have a bad influence on the industry?
Is my influence that bad on the industry?
Maybe that's how others see it.
I may need to have my license taken away and be put aside and I have no doubt that statements I'm making right now will prompt them to consider that.
I have reached a point where I don't care anymore and that saddens me.
I am deeply saddened.
I will put the pressure on and I will force them to make a decision.
My family supports me and I can leave.
The trainer's frustration has grown amid the extended investigation into a cobalt test involving Lidari and his elimination prompted him to say he could "put his licence on the table".

Breaks the race rules.

One of my employees accidentally put mud on his foot.
It could have happened last night.
It could have happened yesterday, and it did.
It happened on race day.
Moody could be disqualified for three months for the day-of-race treatment including the application of a topical ointment, for which stewards opened an inquiry.
It's a joke.
The people that make these rules know nothing about horses.
"We all understand the need for rules, but it has gone too far," Moody said.

Melbourne Storm coach Craig Bellamy responds to wrestling accusations.
Melbourne Storm coach Craig Bellamy has dismissed criticisms of his team's wrestling tactics as "distorted subjects" put forward by the NRL's two top contenders.
Sydney Roosters coach Trent Robinson said referees allowed Melbourne Storm players to "bash up" his team in a tense qualifying final won by the Storm on Friday night at Sydney.

Brisbane Broncos coach Wayne Bennett made a glancing reference to the Storm after his team's qualifying final defeat of North Queensland Cowboys on Saturday night, calling the match a "demonstration" of rugby league and saying the two Queensland teams were not very good at wrestling.
Bellamy defended his side's tackling techniques and said players were simply focusing on "contact" when they tackled.
Bellamy said he gained confidence after two key opposing coaches criticised his team, meaning they were worried about beating the Storm.
"And it doesn't stop there – I didn't hear Trent Robinson complaining about wrestling when we beat them 24-2," Bellamy said on Wednesday.

I can guarantee you that we haven't changed anything all year in our defensive systems and techniques, except that the last six weeks we have really emphasized tackling and that has changed the situation.
Trent has been in this job for three years and he obviously has a great team so he is probably not used to losing and it was a shock to him.
We love how it always happens at this time of the year.
Bellamy contradicted Bennett's idea to "liven up football", reminding his mentor that Bennett's St George-Illawarra Dragons won the 2010 premiership by playing "boring" football.
Wayne talks about exciting football.
He compared Saturday's game with our game on Friday night and he spoke about how exciting the game was,” Bellamy said.
I remember in 2010 St George received a lot of criticism for being a boring team and Wayne said he didn't give a damn.
But now he has a team that can play what we would call exciting football, especially due to the young, fast midfielders.
That's the kind of game you want to play when you have players like that.
He brought this argument in 2010, he now wants everyone to adopt his style of play - not every team has two halves like Anthony Milford and Ben Hunt to play that way.
It gives me more confidence because they say these things because they are somewhat worried about the match against us.
Six weeks ago they probably weren't thinking about us when they were thinking about big games.
Bellamy also highlighted the fact the Storm-Roosters clash was a more fiercely contested affair than the Broncos-Cowboys match.
The Broncos' game was probably a good game, I haven't seen it yet, what was the score? 16-12?
Our match ended 20-18, there were two more tries in our game, does that mean it was a thrilling game?
Or exciting means to take breaks and not score?
For me, there are plans.
If they talk about us, it means that at some point we might meet them.

The Storm have the weekend off after securing the right to host either the North Queensland Cowboys or Cronulla Sharks in next Saturday’s qualifying final at AAMI Park, with tickets going on sale Tuesday morning.
Stevan Hogg used girls' phones to lure paedophiles into sending images
A paedophile used an 11-year-old girl's phone to request pictures of abused children.
Stevan Hogg took the girl's phone while she was sleeping and then logged in to an online messaging service where another user sent him a series of indecent images of children.
The girl woke up later and noticed that her phone was missing, finding it in Hogg's hand as he slept.
She looked at her phone and found disturbing messages and immediately alerted her mother.

After arriving, police officers viewed the five pictures and then analyzed computers found at the address and found “concerning” Internet searches using terms to find indecent images of child subjects.
Hogg claimed he did it to "lure pedophiles" on the Internet before "pretending to be a cop" to scare them.
Prosecutor Eilidh Robertson told Dundee Sheriff Court: "He admitted it is an addiction - that he is addicted to frightening people."
He admitted he carried out the searches, but said he did so because he wanted to pretend to be a police officer and scare off pedophiles.
He was questioned about the conversations he had with the unknown person who sent him the images, and about the fact that he asked the person to send him more pictures.
He said he did it to entice.
He said he doesn't think clearly when he drinks and that he wants to see images of rape and murder.
Mr Robertson added: “When the girl found the messages on the phone, she called out to her mum and was shaking and crying.
The girl saw the indecent images on the phone and the accused was confronted.
The girl was interviewed and told investigators that the defendant used his computer and Playstation to talk to girls who appeared much younger than him.

Last year, on June 14, Hogg, 23, of Ward Road, Dundee, pleaded guilty to charges of making or taking indecent photographs of children, and breaching the conditions of his bail on January 25 this year and failing to appear in court on March 24 of this year.
Defence lawyer Gregor Simpson argued that Hogg should not be placed on the sex offenders register as the offence “did not involve a significant sexual aspect”.
Judge Alistair Carmichael postponed the sentencing until October for social reports.
Hogg was released on bail in this case but remained in custody pending appearances in other cases.
He was placed on the sex offenders register before being sentenced.

Hewlett-Packard to Cut 30,000 Jobs
Hewlett-Packard is expected to lay off between 25,000 and 30,000 employees as part of the company's restructuring and cost-cutting efforts in the services sector.
This year, HP will divide itself into two publicly traded companies, separating its computer and printer business from its rapidly growing corporate hardware and services operations.
The expected layoffs are expected to cost about $2.7 billion during the fourth quarter, the company said.

"These restructurings will give new Hewlett Packard Enterprise a more competitive and sustainable cost structure," said Meg Whitman, HP's president and CEO, who will lead the enterprise unit after the split.
"Hewlett Packard Enterprise will be smaller and more focused than HP is today and will have a portfolio of businesses that will provide the transition to the new style of business," Whitman said.
Operating as a separate company, we are better positioned than ever to satisfy the growing demands of our global customers.
According to a statement from the company, Hewlett Packard Enterprise will have annual revenues of more than $50 billion, and will "focus on providing integrated solutions to enterprises."
The company was founded in 1930 by Stanford University graduates Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard, producing electrical equipment and whose garage in Palo Alto was called the “cradle of Silicon Valley.”
HP has gone through a massive restructuring to adapt to the shift from traditional computers to mobile devices.

The move by HP, the world's second-largest personal computer maker and one of the largest technology companies in the United States, is the most recent in a string of such moves, based on the idea that companies that focus better in one direction perform better.
FriendsFest: the comedy show that taught us important lessons about male friendship
The absence of such characters in television shows is glaring, given that the need for men to open up is more urgent than ever, with suicide rates among young men reaching a 15-year high.
In 2013, suicide was the leading cause of death among men aged 20-45 in Britain, and remains three times more common among men than women.

In an attempt to address the problem, the Campaign Against Living Miserably (CALM) has designated 2015 as the year of the man, seeking to challenge the culture that prevents men from asking for help when they need it.
Friendship is at the heart of the fight to achieve this challenge.

A recent study of more than 2,000 high school students who showed signs of depression found that if the patient was surrounded by enough friends "with a healthy mood", their chances of recovery doubled.
Similarly, for people who are not depressed, a circle of mentally healthy friends cuts the risk of developing mental disorders in half.
Of course, in order for friendship to have an effect, it must first be accessible.
In this era of social media-driven communications, where style is prioritized over substance, the immediacy of the response often takes precedence over contact with meaning.
Our digital lives have doubled the need to create the appearance of a strong, fun and successful personality, even though in reality isolation is the norm.

This superficial success is dominated by what psychologists call extrinsic values; money, image, social status, all at the expense of intrinsic values - our inner desire for personal development and friendship - which more deeply affect our mental health.
The billionaire inventor of a video game has recently explained that money doesn't really buy happiness.
The beauty of Friends was that it focused attention on this idea.
The characters were not defined by their jobs, but by their personalities, which they showed by interacting as friends.

The camaraderie of Joey and Chandler's frequent hugs, the moments when they watch football in their comfy armchairs and Ross's passion for Rachel came from the fact that men can relate to this situation, even though they often shy away from exploring their feelings completely.
As one social worker explained to me: ...“My role of listening to suicidal and depressed people showed me how even the smallest interactions with friends can make a difference.”
Often the people who contact us don't feel able to talk to their friends.
The old adage to pull yourself together is strong, as is the sense of being perceived as weak if you open up about your problems.
Friends is one of the shows that comes to mind when I try to offer more long-term psychological coping mechanisms.
The series highlighted the small moments of friendship between men.
As helpful as external, objective intervening by phone might be, long-term support comes from family members and close friends.
So if you're attending Comedy Central's FriendsFest this weekend, complete with fully recreated sets to celebrate the event, why not invite your friends for a coffee at Central Perk.
Or better yet, if you see someone standing alone in Starbucks, smile and say hello.
You never know what difference your friendship could make.
Friends is being broadcast by Comedy Central from start to finish - all 236 episodes - during #FriendsFest
Di Maria Scores, Helps PSG to Ease Past Malmo
Angel Di Maria celebrates with Blaise Matuidi and Edinson Cavani after scoring against Malmo.
Angel Di Maria scored on his Champions League debut on Tuesday to help Paris Saint-Germain beat Swedish side Malmo.
Now here's the report on the game and reaction to the match.
Angel Di Maria and Edinson Cavani did the job as Paris Saint-Germain began their Champions League campaign with a comfortable 2-0 win over Malmo at the Parc des Princes on Tuesday.

Di Maria scored in less than four minutes of his Champions League debut for PSG, putting the French champions ahead despite missing a string of chances before Cavani sealed the win in the 61st minute.

Drawn in Group A along with Real Madrid and Shakhtar Donetsk, PSG needed a strong start against the Swedish champions as the French side's goal is not just to qualify for the knockout rounds but also to improve on their quarterfinal exits in each of the last three tournaments.

But, although they took the points, Laurent Blanc's side were far from a perfect picture, with Zlatan Ibrahimovic missing the chance to score against the team from his hometown and the club where he started his glittering career in 1999.

"It's not easy to win at home or away in the Champions League, so winning 2-0 creates problems for our opponents and establishes a comfortable difference from the next-placed teams, even if there are still aspects that we have to work on over the course of the season," Blanc said.
It is a good sign.
We wanted to win and we did, although I'm sorry we didn't manage to score another one or two goals.
Ibrahimovic returned from injury with one of three changes to the Paris team, with a 2-2 draw at home to Bordeaux in Ligue 1 at the weekend, but Di Maria grabbed the limelight in the fourth minute.

Last month when he switched from Manchester United, the Argentine forward was billed as the man who would take PSG to the next level in Europe and he demonstrated this when he burst on to Marco Verratti's pass behind the Malmo defence before striking an incredible shot into the top right corner of Johan Wiland's net.
But if anyone expected PSG to get the victory with a snap of their fingers, they were disappointed.
Malmo, who beat Celtic in the play-offs to reach this stage and lined up with nine players with international experience and a five-man defence and two holding midfielders, were a tough opponent.
But their attack was not impressive, with the exception of Nikola Djurdjic's shot that went past Kevin Trapp in the 34th minute.

PSG players, however, slowed down the pace several times, giving several useless passes and failing to finish their actions, even Ibrahimovic missed no fewer than five attempts in the first half and was then replaced by Cavani even after the game restarted.
Ibrahimovic proved more adept at setting up his teammates, though, his pass to Di Maria was deflected by Wiland into the net in the 52nd minute.
The second goal was scored in the end after an hour of play, thanks to Cavani, the Uruguayan who scored his sixth goal of the season after Ibrahimovic made a pass from Maxwell's cross.
The goal ended Malmo's hopes of levelling the tie and only a superb Wiland save from David Luiz kept the score intact before substitute Ezequiel Lavezzi had a goal ruled out in stoppage time.
Malmo manager Age Hareide said later that PSG were a class apart, adding: "The last Champions League game we played was in December last year."
Since then, I have only played in the Swedish League, which is not at the same level.
Qualifications are not enough.
Hats off to PSG.
They played an excellent game.
Glencore raises $2.5 billion from share sale
Swiss mining giant Glencore, hit by a fall in commodity prices, has raised $2.5 billion from a share sale as part of a broad plan to sharply reduce its debt.
Glencore, listed on the London Stock Exchange, said it sold new shares worth $2.5 billion to help pay off the debt.
After losing 57% of its market value this year, the company is grappling with collapsing commodity prices, as slowing economic activity in China influences demand and wreaks havoc across markets.
Glencore's preference share rights issue helped push its shares higher on the London Stock Exchange (LSE) in early trading on Wednesday.
Shares climbed 2.77% to 131.60 pence in the FTSE 100 index, which opened 0.69% higher.
Glencore has revealed plans to sell shares worth $2.5 billion as part of wider plans to cover almost a third of its $30 billion debt.
The company sold the new shares at 125 pence per share, 2.4% below Tuesday's closing price.
It sold 1.3 billion shares, or 9.99% of the group.
Concern about China's slowing economy has led to a substantial increase in the price of iron ore, which is up by about half, while coal, copper and other commodities have fallen by 20-40%.
Xi urges wider global economic expansion
President Xi Jinping told a reform group on Tuesday that the economy should be opened more widely to the outside world to feed growth.
“China needs to engage in attracting foreign investment and expertise and improving its opening-up policies,” Xi said at the 16th meeting of the Central Leading Group for Deepening Overall Reform.
Promoting openness and encouraging reform will bring fresh impetus and vitality and make room for economic growth, Xi said.

The leadership group adopted a series of guidelines, including a negative list for market entry regulation, relaxing customs control policies, encouraging state-owned enterprises to absorb private capital and reorganizing the resident registration system.
The statement said a negative list will be drawn up to identify the sectors and activities where investments are not allowed.
The system will be tested gradually and improved through trial programs.

The statement said the measure was important because it would give the market a greater role in the allocation of resources, ensuring a business environment based on legislation and providing more openness to the market.
State authorities will also reduce controls over the powers it delegates to companies, ensuring that companies decide how to run their businesses.
China will also allow border regions to explore new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms for promoting regional growth, the statement said.
In an attempt to open up state-controlled sectors, more sectors will be opened to private investment.

"The state authorities will not change their policy on foreign investment and will protect the legitimate interests of foreign-invested companies and provide them with better services," the statement said.
Additionally, it will be easier for foreign citizens to apply for permanent residence permits or so-called green cards, streamlining the requirements and speeding up the application process.
The meeting also discussed the guarantee of lawyers' right to practice, and the education of judges and prosecutors.
Premier Li Keqiang and leaders Liu Yunshan and Zhang Gaoli also attended the meeting, according to a statement issued after the meeting.

Today's government proposal did not satisfy us, otherwise we would not have reached the point of calling the leadership of our federations.
The 10 percent that was promised today is less than we expected.

Ponta: In the future, health and education will be the areas in which we will invest all the money we have

According to him, on Thursday there will be a meeting of FSLI in which will participate representatives of the Government to present to representatives of the trade unions in the country the proposal for a salary increase, and the trade unionists will decide whether to accept the Government's offer.
The prime minister told unionists that the government is trying to send the salary law as quickly as possible to Parliament, so that it can come into force on December 1.
The bill provides for increasing the salaries in the educational system by 25% of the total 70% increase, which is to be phased in in the next four years.
Victor Ponta has also promised the unionists that all judicial sentences will be paid in 2016.
Migrant Crisis: Tragedy in the Aegean Sea
At least 22 migrants drowned Tuesday in Turkish territorial waters after a boat carrying them sank.
Among the victims were 11 women and 5 children, AFP reported, according to Yahoo News.
The boat was in the Aegean Sea and was heading for the Greek island of Kos.
Turkey's coast guard said it had rescued 249 people from the capsized boat, but it was not immediately clear what their nationalities were.
Two other people died on Monday while trying to cross the Aegean Sea.
Also on the weekend, 34 migrants, including 4 infants and 11 children, drowned off the Greek island of Farmakonisi, located 15 kilometers off the Turkish coast.
The situation was similar: the vessel was carrying more people than it could handle, so it sank.
The route has become popular in recent years for migrants seeking to escape war and hardship in countries like Syria and Iraq.
More than 100 stewardesses fired for being too fat
Air India has laid off about 130 flight attendants because they are overweight, the company announced last week.

The state-run company said the decision was taken for security reasons and recent government regulations, but critics claim the move is "ridiculous" and "shockingly sexist," The Washington Post reported.
The mass dismissal is the latest development in a decade-long battle between the company and its larger flight attendants.
The weight limit dates back to the 1980s, when Air India started using charts for ideal weight and height.
In 2006, Air India fired nine stewardesses deemed "exceptionally overweight," saying it could "adversely affect their reflexes and impinge on the agility required to perform emergency duties."
The flight attendants sued, won, and were rehired, but the company fired them again in 2009.
"All efforts to make them lose weight have failed," a company spokesperson said at the time.
A Steaua footballer gives lessons to Gigi Becali: What decision he has made
A footballer from Steaua gives lessons to Gigi Becali about how to promote young players.
If the champion's financier decided to close the football academy in which he invested a considerable amount, defender Paul Papp opened a football school.
The "Paul Papp" Academy will operate in the city of Dej, the children from the locality are expected at a first selection action.
I am extremely happy to be in this stage of launching the football Academy that carries my name.
For me, it's extremely important to find talented kids who can play football without having to worry about material issues at training.
They must have just one concern: that of playing football as well as possible.
The technical details should not be their concern.
They need to make the most of their talent.
This is what the Paul Papp Football Academy wants to do.
"I'm expecting Mayor Costan Morar to attend the first child selection event, to show them he is with them," the football player Papp told dejeanul.ro.
The kids up to the age of 11 are expected at the Steaua Academy.
The party wants to govern.
The interim PSD President Liviu Dragnea declared on Tuesday that the entire party wishes to remain in power, and, if the Prime Minister wants, this decision will be formalized at the PSD Congress.
I understand that Mr. Ponta is waiting for this decision from the PSD Congress, everyone wants to be in power, the whole party.
If it is deemed necessary to formalize it through a Congressional resolution, we will do so.
There will be no emotion about this.
