"There were no elements, no voices in the party, no opinions in the party that would give anyone the uncertainty of governing or give anyone the impression that someone in the party does not want the PSD to remain in government, in the current government, with the current prime minister," Dragnea said at the end of the meeting of the PSD National Permanent Bureau.
PSD announces when it will hold a congress - what will be decided then

Prime Minister Victor Ponta said on Tuesday that it is important that, at the PSD Congress, aside from electing the leadership, a clear message is given as to whether the party wants to continue governing or decides to move into the opposition.
Dragnea: I will announce on Monday if I will run for a position in Congress
On the other hand, Liviu Dragnea will announce next Monday if he will run for a leadership position at the upcoming Congress.
I will weigh in on Monday, after the Executive Committee, if the congress date is also set.
"I will announce if I will run for a position within the party leadership", Dragnea said at the end of PSD's National Permanent Bureau meeting on Tuesday.
Asked if his hesitation to announce his candidacy was related to the case, Dragnea said he faced no such problem.
I don't have a problem with that question, but it seems fair and honest to all of my colleagues in the party to announce or not announce a candidacy when the formal date for the Congress is set.
"This is the only motivation,” Dragnea said.
Most of the PSD branches have proposed an extraordinary congress on October 11, and the exact date of the congress will be decided on Monday by the Executive Committee of the party.
Career Fair Offers Thousands of Jobs at 200 Firms
More than 200 companies are expected to participate in the autumn edition of the Career Fair (TdC), an event that will take place in Brasov, Chisinau, Cluj-Napoca, Iasi, Sibiu and Tirgu Mures.
The companies are offering several thousand job openings, internship and training opportunities, with some of them already announced on the official website www.targuldecariere.ro.
Recruitment is a Growing Priority for Companies

According to the statistics drawn up based on the 100 editions of the Career Fair held so far, the majority of companies are interested, besides the actual recruitment, in developing a strong employer brand among the young people: 97% of their representatives stated that they want to return to the future editions, while 94% said they recommend the Career Fair as a recruitment and employer branding solution.
There are also cases where companies choose to do the hiring at the same time, just so they can organize the recruitment more efficiently.

The list of companies that will participate in the TdC event in October and November 2015 includes: Arvato Bertelsmann, Bombardier, Bosch, CIE Matricon, Competence Call Center, DB Schenker, Delphi, Office Depot, Preh, Renault, Schaeffler, Stefanini and Sykes.
Candidate Profile
Most of the TdC participants looking for a job are students (59.70%), followed by university graduates (23.05%) and master graduates (10.38%).
The least educated were those who had completed their PhDs – 0.67 per cent – and those who had finished high school or secondary school – 6.2 per cent.
As for their field of expertise, most of them work in IT and Software, in the finance and banking sector, in insurance, marketing, advertising and media, or in the auto/construction industry.
It is no longer a surprise that the IT sector is in a constant rise in the country.
As a result, another edition of the IT Career Fair will take place this year, a niche event dedicated exclusively to the enthusiasts and specialists in this field.
Among the business giants present at the 7th edition of the event are Accenture, Endava, KFC, McDonald's, msg systems, Siemens, Steelcase, Unicredit Business Integrated Solutions and Yardi Systems.
Career Fair, 100th edition
Founded in Cluj in 2006, the Career Fair is today the largest career events network in Romania and the Republic of Moldova.

The autumn edition will take place in Chisinau (Army House, October 2-3), Iasi (Palas, October 6-7), Brasov (Army House, October 14-15), Cluj Global (Polivalenta Hall, October 20-21), Cluj IT (Polivalenta Hall, October 22-23), Sibiu (Business Center, October 28-29) and Targu-Mures (National Theatre, November 5).
Details about the companies registered so far and about the Career Fair can be found on www.targuldecariere.ro.
An Italian man was caught at the Bors border crossing with immigrants hidden in a truck
Two Sri Lankan citizens were caught at the Bors border crossing on Monday as they were trying to cross the border illegally, hidden in the trailer of a truck driven by an Italian citizen.
According to the Border Police, following investigations, it was found that the two had paid about 4,000 euros to the driver in order to be transported to France.

During the routine check, border police noticed a large travel bag in the truck's cabin, containing personal belongings for several people, which prompted them to carry out a thorough check of the transport vehicle.
During that operation the border police uncovered two male persons hidden among the plastic crates in the trailer of the truck.
The checks showed that the two men, aged 28, are citizens of Sri Lanka and asylum seekers in Romania.

"During the investigations, the young people stated that they wanted to go to France, for which they contacted a compatriot, through whom they met the Italian driver, who offered to carry them to the destination, where they had to receive 2,000 euros per person," the Border Police said in a statement.
The two migrants were charged with "criminal activity involving an attempt to illegally cross the state border."

Also, Pompeo B., a 45-year-old Italian citizen who was driving a Renault Magnum truck registered in Romania and carrying plastic containers for an Italian company, was detained for 24 hours and will be presented to the Bihor Tribunal with a proposal for preventive arrest.
How satisfied are Romanians in couples: Men versus Women
Most Romanians are satisfied with their relationships.
This is the conclusion of a study conducted on the occasion of the arrival to Romania of John Gray, the famous author of the bestseller "Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus".
A total of 62 percent of respondents said they were 'very satisfied' or 'satisfied' with the overall quality of their relationship.

"However, 18 percent said they were 'slightly dissatisfied' and 'very dissatisfied' with their relationship, while 18 percent said they were 'just right'", the study concluded, according to a statement sent to Ziare.com on Tuesday.
The situation is somewhat different when men's and women's responses are analyzed separately.
In this way, 28 percent of men are very satisfied, 39 percent satisfied, 17 percent acceptable, 6 percent very dissatisfied and 8% slightly dissatisfied.
For women, 33 percent declared themselves satisfied, 24 percent very satisfied, 8 percent very dissatisfied, 14 percent slightly dissatisfied and 19 percent chose the right category.
When we look at the degree of satisfaction (positive), we will observe that men are more satisfied.
As for the neutral (appropriate) condition, we see a two-percent difference.
"The same is true with the very unsatisfied situation, the biggest difference being registered in the slightly unsatisfied response where we see a difference of 6 percent," the report also said.
The study also showed that one quarter of Romanians (26%) spend one hour or less together, 18% spend between five and eight hours together, and 45% spend between two and four hours together.

The study's authors found that "Romanians feel the need for a bit more adventure in their lives (24%), followed by affection (21%), money (21%), safety (20%), new (19%), sex (19%), respect 18%, trust 17%, pleasure 17%, connectivity 17%, knowledge 16%, protection 14%, importance 14%, learning 12%, freedom 11%, self-knowledge 10% and control 7%".
The survey was conducted by Extreme Training between June 1 and September 1 among 1,369 people, with a margin of error of 2.6%.
Europe has embarrassed itself again

German Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel said on Tuesday that Europe had "made a fool of itself" after failing at a ministerial meeting in Brussels on Monday to agree on a quota system to distribute refugees within the European Union.
"Once again Europe has shamed itself last night," said Sigmar Gabriel, who is also economy minister in Chancellor Angela Merkel's government, AFP reported.
Germany's Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere has suggested reducing EU structural funds for countries that refuse to accept refugee quotas.

European interior ministers failed to reach a deal on Monday on the mandatory distribution of 120,000 refugees, requested last week by the European Commission to address one of the worst migration crises in Europe since 1945.
He was mayor for just half an hour
The interim mayor of the city of Tuzla in Constanta county held the post for just half an hour, due to prosecutors from the National Anti-Corruption Directorate.
Taner Resit was elected to lead the town, replacing the former mayor, Constantin Micu, who was convicted of embezzlement, informs B1 TV.
The county prefect, Ion Constantin, was waiting for him at the county's headquarters to make the official announcement at 4 p.m., but he did not arrive.
The reason?
Taner Resit was summoned at 2 PM at the DNA Constanta headquarters.
After two and a half hours of hearings, he was taken into custody for 24 hours.
As a result, he was mayor for only 30 minutes.
Prosecutors say he is accused of extorting a businessman from August 16 to September 8, in complicity with Stefan Radu, a businessman who wanted to obtain 48,000 euros from him, Adevarul reported.
The two men threatened the manager, drove away customers, prevented them from entering the store, changed the locks and sequestered the company's goods.
Furthermore, on September 8, Stefan Radu would have beaten the administrator in the presence of the deputy mayor.
Thousands of people passed by to place a candle

Thousands of people came to the coffin carrying the body of Corneliu Vadim Tudor, more people visiting the St. George Church than at the consecration of the church or the Great Feast of St. Nicholas, said Wednesday parish priest Emil Caramizaru.
Hundreds of people of all ages wait in line, stretching from the church entrance to the side streets, to pass by the catafalque where Corneliu Vadim Tudor's mortal remains lie.
People wait for roughly an hour to get into St. George's New Church, where groups of 40 people are permitted to enter.
About 300 people per hour have passed by the coffin of Corneliu Vadim Tudor on Wednesday.

Thousands of people from Bucharest, but also from Cluj, Baia Mare, Iasi, Constanta and Craiova came, starting Tuesday, to pay homage to Corneliu Vadim Tudor, more people than we had only in the 300th anniversary of the church and in the Great consecration of St. Nicholas.

"Corneliu Vadim Tudor was at the 300th anniversary consecration and he sat next to the members of the Holy Synod, Patriarch Daniel and the representatives of the five patriarchs who participated to the consecration," said the parish priest of the Bucharest church, Emil Caramizaru.
According to him, people come with flowers and candles in hand, they stand quietly and wait in line, as if it were a religious holiday.
The behavior of these people is extraordinary, they sit quietly, with dignity, children, old people, people in crutches, as if they were at a great religious celebration.
"It is touching to see them waiting to pay their last respects to Vadim Tudor," parish priest Emil Caramizaru said.

According to him, at the request of Corneliu Vadim Tudor's family, the church will stay open on the night from Wednesday to Thursday, the previous night being closed at 01:00 and reopened in the morning at 07:00.

He said the last service will be held Thursday morning at 10:00 am at Saint George Church at kilometer 0, after which the coffin with the body of Vadim Tudor will be transported to Ghencea Civil Cemetery, where the funeral will be held, with a religious and military ceremony.

The parish priest said that Vadim Tudor came to the church very often, especially in the evenings, after 8 p.m. and he asked him every time to open the reliquary with the relics of Saint Nicholas, and then he remained there to pray for a few minutes.
He would come here very often, usually in the evening, after 8 p.m., and he would ask me to open the reliquary with St. Nicholas's relics and pray.
He said it was a great blessing this Brancoveanu church.
He told me: "Brother Emil, think of the people who were here: Brancoveanu, Eminescu, Mihai Viteazul, who touched the holy hand of Saint Nicholas".
"'Can you imagine what a blessing it is for this country,' Vadim told me," the parish priest said.
Corneliu Vadim Tudor will be buried on Thursday at the Ghencea Civil cemetery with military honors.
The Senate leadership on Tuesday rejected a request by Corneliu Vadim Tudor's wife that the late senator's coffin be laid in the legislative chamber.
Corneliu Vadim Tudor was born on November 28, 1949 in Bucharest, he was a writer, politician and journalist.
He was the founder of the Greater Romania Party, a former member of the European Parliament and a former senator.
What is happening to Darren Cahill
Simona Halep is facing a crucial decision for her career, as she has to choose whether to continue collaborating with her coach Darren Cahill.
The two have worked together this year as part of the Adidas Player Development program, and the Australian coach has been with the Romanian player only at the major tournaments.
Simona only had praise for Cahill, who appears to be the only coach who has managed to impose himself on the capricious player.
However, the Adidas program will come to an end this year, and Halep will have to decide whether to offer Cahill a substantial contract or terminate the collaboration.
We do not yet know exactly what will happen.
We'll talk and see.
"After Singapore, I will be able to give an answer", said Simona during a press conference.
Darren Cahill is one of the most expensive tennis coaches today, asking for a contract valued at about a million dollars a year.
In addition, the Australian is a sports commentator, a profession he wouldn't like to give up at the moment.
The last tournament that Simona and Cahill will work together is the WTA finals in Singapore.
It was not normal, I was not respected
Victor Piturca has revealed how he parted ways with the Romanian national team last fall.

The former coach admitted that he did not get along with the president of the Romanian Football Federation, Razvan Burleanu, after he took the place of Mircea Sandu, and thus he decided to leave the national team.
He eventually offered the Federation President a substantial increase in salary in order to stay, but was refused.
Right now I don't regret leaving the national team.
At the time, I felt sorry, leaving a job behind.
So I thought it was good for me and I believe it was good for me.
What happened to me when I was coach, it wasn't normal, I wasn't respected, my work wasn't respected.
I worked well with those who were here before, but when Burleanu came to the Federation, he came with a preconceived idea, he didn't know me, he heard different opinions about me in the press.
I didn't change because it was very hard at that moment, because of the results we had, plus the financial situation.
We continued our work, everything went very well, and he probably changed his mind.
But I wanted to leave.
If they really wanted me to stay, I proposed a contract extension.
We have about 400 thousand euros per year, I was going to have about 600 thousand euros.
I did not speak with Burleanu, but with his right hand.
"He agreed, but only if we finished first in the group," Victor Piturca told Dolce Sport.
Victor Piturca resigned from the Romanian national team in the fall of last year, although the team had good results in the preliminaries of Euro 2016.
The technician accepted the offer to train in Saudi Arabia, immediately taking over the Al Ittihad team.
Tanks and Water Cannons at the Border

Hungarian police deployed Humvee military vehicles equipped with machine guns to the border with Serbia on Wednesday after violent clashes where water cannons and tear gas were used against migrants trying to enter from Serbia despite Hungary's erection of a barbed-wire fence.
At least 20 police officers and two children are injured in the clashes, Russia Today reports.
So far, 20 police officers have been injured, and the ambulance service has taken two children who were injured after being thrown over the security fence.
"We will rebuild the fence and strengthen it and we will protect Hungary's security by all means," said Hungarian Prime Minister's security adviser Gyorgy Bakondi.
Police tried to control the crowd with water cannons and tear gas as protesters threw plastic bottles, stones and pieces of pavement.
Authorities said at least several dozen migrants broke through the fence between the border towns of Roszke and Horgos and managed to enter the country.
Hungary's Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto has demanded Serbia take action against "very aggressive" migrants at their common border.
There are also reports that Serbian forces have beefed up their border police presence.
Following Wednesday's incident, Budapest suspended the border crossing at Roszke-Horgos for 30 days.
Hungary is in a concerted effort to close its borders to stem the flow of migrants.

After announcing on Tuesday that he would build a fence along the border with Serbia, to the vehement protests of Bucharest, the Hungarian prime minister announced that he would also put up a fence at the border with Croatia.
Rare disease affects a man
American Nick Hess was suspected by his family of being an alcoholic. His wife even filmed him when he was drunk, barely able to stand and his words were hard to understand.
Although the 35-year-old man said he had not consumed alcohol, it was obvious that he was in a state of intoxication.
When she first accused me of being drunk when I didn't drink, I thought she was crazy.
"But friends and family thought 'maybe he's drinking on his own, he's a secret alcoholic,'" he told the Mirror.
When a Columbus, Ohio man watched his wife’s video of him, he simply didn't recognize himself: "I was looking into my eyes and I wasn't there."
'It was horrible, I didn't remember anything.'
In addition, his wife, who, although she had doubted him for a while, eventually went with him to innumerable doctors, remembers that Nick's breath smelled of alcohol.

The moment that really made Nick think was when, after a minor accident when he was hit by another car, his blood alcohol level was found to be three times over the legal limit, although the night before he'd only had one beer.
After years and countless investigations, it was discovered that Nick suffers from a very rare disease, "Auto-brewery syndrome".
In effect, its body makes all the carbohydrates it consumes ferment, turning them into alcohol.
The person who suspected that this might be Nick's illness was his wife.
There is no cure for the disease, but since giving up carbohydrates, Nick has not experienced any such episodes.
He destroyed a Mercedes with a golf club
A man in South Korea destroyed his Mercedes S63 car in protest at poor service he received from his local dealer.
The man attacked his car with a golf club, causing enough damage to put the car out of commission, BT reports.
The entire scene was filmed and the video was posted on the Internet, to the amusement of those who saw it.
The man claimed the car had defects that put his and his family's lives at risk.
His anger came when the dealer from whom he purchased the car failed to address the problem, as they had agreed.

The government approved on Wednesday the "National Immigration Strategy for the Period 2015-2018" and the "Action Plan for 2015", documents that are considered to be "another stage in Romania's efforts to modernize the process of managing immigration on the country's territory", according to a press release.

The source said the strategy aims to efficiently manage immigration, including general strategic objectives, specific objectives and action lines that reflect the policies established at the European level, adapted to national realities.

Given the problems encountered by the states in the immediate vicinity of Romania, measures are taken for the unified and coherent management of situations determined by the possible appearance of an influx of illegal immigrants on the territory of Romania, generated by crisis situations of a political, social, economic or military nature.

"The Romanian authorities will contribute to the creation of a flexible admission system, but at the same time, they will pay special attention to citizens coming from countries with migration potential or that may affect national security", the source added.

The strategy identifies a number of factors that can influence immigration and asylum, including the continuation of the Syrian conflict, the reactivation of the conflict in Iraq, the continuation of an unstable situation in Romania's neighboring regions, including Ukraine and Transnistria, and the perpetuation and escalation of the Israeli-Palestinian armed conflict.

In turn, the document also sets out some general strategic goals related to immigration, such as promoting legal migration, stricter controls on the legality of the residence of third-country nationals on the Romanian territory and adequate application of removal and restrictive measures, improving the national asylum system.
The national strategy also includes specific objectives relevant to the implementation of the general strategic objectives.

These are: facilitating the access of third-country nationals to the Romanian territory to meet the needs of the labour market, facilitating the access of third-country nationals to Romanian higher education institutions for the domains and professions identified as being in shortage.

Regarding the Action Plan for 2015, the Government considers that it represents "a means by which concrete activities are established that will lead to the creation of a flexible system for stopping the growing migration phenomenon".
Romania, in a European labor market ranking

Latvia, Romania and Bulgaria registered the highest growth in total labour cost among European Union member states in the second quarter of the year, compared with the same period of 2014, according to data published on Wednesday by the European Union's statistics office Eurostat.
The index refers to employers' personnel expenses.
Thus, in the period April-June 2015, the total cost of labour rose by 1.9% in the European Union and by 1.6% in the euro zone.
Romania ranks 3rd in EU in labor cost growth
The highest increase was reported in Latvia (7.9%), Romania (7.7%), Bulgaria (6.8%), Estonia (5.5%) and Lithuania (4.3%).
The only EU states where the hourly labour cost fell in the second quarter of this year were Greece (minus 2.9%), Cyprus (minus 1.2%) and Italy (minus 0.4%).
The rise in labour costs in Romania in the April – June 2015 period is mainly due to the increase in hourly labour costs in industry and services, by 7.9% and 7.6%, respectively.
In the construction sector, Romania recorded an increase of 5.8% in hourly labor costs.
TVR management activity report rejected in committees: Stelian Tanase risks dismissal
The culture committees of the Parliament rejected on Wednesday the activity report of the Board of Administration of the Romanian Television Society for 2014.
Seventeen parliamentarians voted to reject the report, one against rejecting it (senator Varujan Vosganian) and one abstained.
The report will be forwarded to the Joint Standing Committees.
They are expected to decide next week.
It will be debated in the next plenary meeting.
"I think given this situation, it will be done relatively quickly," said the president of the Senate's culture committee, Georgica Severin.

He added that "it was common sense" that the TVR leadership should be present at the meeting, considering that at the meeting of the Culture Committees no representative of the TVR leadership was present.
It was a good idea for the TVR leadership to be present because no one here has been subjected to personal attacks or anything like that.

The invitation was made to the Board members last night at an approximate time because we didn't know the exact time, but today, after the joint meetings of the bureaux, I personally sent a fax to the management of TVR to invite them.
I think that when you are summoned, being a civil servant, paid with public taxes and you are summoned to a meeting of the joint committees, you come even if you don't like it.
"It is your job, you are at an institution subordinated to Parliament", Severin said after the meeting of the joint culture committees of the Parliament.
He added that the meeting discussed the financial aspects of the institution on the basis of the negative opinion of the Budget Committees.
We have seen that the debts have continued. The idea was to pay them off this year, but the historic debts have not been paid.

"I'll remind you that it wasn't my fault or the fault of any of the other committees that we lost that agreement with the banks and the tax authorities, this is a clear management problem," Severin said.
He said that after the activity report is rejected by the joint plenum, elections will be held for a new Board of Directors, which will elect the institution's general director.
I don't know who will be proposed for this position.
No miracles will be done.
It is important to take political decisions in order for this institution to function.
I'm not going to lie to you and say that a genius is going to arrive and stand in line and fight.
I hope those who decide, the Parliament's plenary, will choose with much reason the people who will lead the TVR.
There have to be people who know what's going on there, who have experience and who have a lot of integrity and respect for the institution and the tradition.

I don't know who is going to be, if you ask me what qualities they must have - common sense in dealing with employees because there is a huge number of petitions that come from employees, complaints, dismissals.
"When you receive 50, 60, 70 such notices, something is rotten and we are talking about a financial situation that is a disaster," said the president of the Senate's culture commission.

Although he did not appear in Parliament, Stelian Tanase, the president-general manager of the Romanian Public Television (TVR), sent a letter to the Chamber of Deputies President Valeriu Zgonea, asking Parliament to consider a series of measures that would lead to the saving and the guaranteeing of the independence of the public television, both economic and political, among which the indexing of the TV tax.

In a letter, Stelian Tanase requested, among other things, the indexing of the TV tax, modifying and completing the HG 978/2003 regarding the tax for the television public service, in order to update the provisions to the level of technological changes, as well as to regulate the procedure of control in the payment of the TV tax and the establishment of the offenses and the application of sanctions and penalties.
He also wants to issue a regulation making it mandatory for all electricity providers to become SRTv tax collection agents, with ANRE getting involved in regulating that activity.
According to him it is necessary to set a maximum commission rate of 5% of revenues.

Stelian Tanase calls for the reduction of the VAT rate for activities specific to the public TV station and the contribution for the CNC to be decreased from 15% to the level of 3%, but also for the modification of the law 41/1994, in the sense of the possibility of receiving budgetary allocations/financing for the purchase of licenses for major cultural and sporting events - the Football World Cup, the Golden Stag, Eurovision.

He claims that SRTv will fall into insolvency in the next few months given that the labor code requires the employer to enforce the court decisions, even if they are not final, and salary rights are honored with a priority over any other obligation.
The TVR administration has made constant efforts to reduce personnel and TV production costs.

"Thus, there have been reduced travel and other cost-generating activities, a series of commercial contracts were renegotiated, and in late July, the TVR News channel was closed," the TVR president said in a letter.
Tanase believes that the disastrous financial situation cannot be remedied only through its own efforts.
"Without the support of state institutions (Government, Parliament, Presidency), Romanian Television will, sooner or later, find itself unable to fulfill its public mission," the letter reads.
The Chamber of Deputies' leadership decided to send the letter to the Culture Committee.
Vasile Blaga's son in law faces trial
Vasile Blaga's son-in-law, Ionut Andrei Rudeanu, was sent to trial by prosecutors of the Court of Appeal of Bucharest.
He is accused of tax evasion in a case that caused losses of around 600,000 euros and is under judicial supervision.
Andrei Rudeanu was placed under arrest on May 22.
He set up the security firm Axis Corporate Security SRL, along with his mother, in April 2009, one year after he married Vasile Blaga's daughter Agathe.

The investigation revealed that, in order to avoid paying taxes and duties to the state budget, representatives of a company that provides security services would have created a criminal circuit, made up of several commercial companies, through which fictitious transactions would have been noted.

In fact, in the accounting of the company there were recorded fictitious purchases of services which, in reality, were not provided and the state budget was thus prejudiced by approximately 600,000 euros, the Romanian Police explained in a press release.
Sheikhs have decided Sanmartean's fate
Al-Ittihad chiefs have decided the fate of Lucian Sanmartean.
Although the Arab press reported that Sanmartean's departure from Ittihad was imminent, the player's agent Ladislau Boloni, Arcadie Zaporojanu, said this will not happen.
Boloni is very pleased with Sanmartean.
Lucian is playing starter in every match, and he is doing well.
The sheikhs realized that he is the best and that it would be a mistake if they gave up on him.
They could have brought another, better player, but it didn't work out.
"There were several discussions, such as that with Mbark Boussoufa, but nothing has materialized," Zaporojanu told Digi Sport.
Lucian Sanmartean joined Al-Ittihad at the beginning of this year.
Ilie Sarbu was elected vice-president of the Court of Accounts
The Senate voted Wednesday to appoint PSD Senator Ilie Sarbu, the father-in-law of Prime Minister Victor Ponta, as vice president of the Audit Authority of the Court of Accounts.
There were 290 votes in favor and 108 votes against, according to Mediafax.
The vote was secret, by ballot.
PNL representatives were the only ones to vote against the proposal, Digi24 informs.

Liberals have criticized the appointment of Sarbu to this position and announced that they will challenge it at the Constitutional Court, given that he has a file at the National Anti-Corruption Department (DNA), but does not have the necessary training and experience.
Ilie Sarbu has 30 days, according to law, to resign from the Senate, as his new position at the Court of Accounts does not allow him to do politics anymore.

The PSD Senator will take the position of vice president of the Audit Authority of the Court of Accounts, left vacant after Ioan Anton was dismissed, following a decision of the Constitutional Court in September 2014, which ruled that he was appointed unconstitutionally.
Surprise from one of the sexiest actors: I grew up in the kitchen
As Bradley Cooper is set to play a chef in his upcoming movie "Burnt", the actor has made a revelation that might surprise his fans.
In a recent interview, he said that he grew up more in the kitchen: "I worked most of my life as a cook."
He revealed that he had been working in the kitchen since he was 15, when he worked for a Greek restaurant, and then continued the same path in college.
The actor explained that his mother is Italian, so he spent his childhood cooking with his Italian grandmother, ContactMusic reports.
Asked what his plans were at that time, Bradley Cooper said he had never been the kind of person to make five-year plans, "or even two-year plans".
"It's not really motivating to me to have a map," he said.
"I have dreams, things you'd laugh at if I told you," he said, adding that what he wanted as a child has come true.
Now 40 years old, the actor admitted he sees himself directing in the near future, following the example of Clint Eastwood, who started directing at the same age.
Ponta, Accused of Uncontrolled slander and Irrational Statements

Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto has strongly condemned the statement of Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta that political decision-makers in Hungary are "not any better than those in Syria, Libya or other countries from where refugees are fleeing."
"Yesterday, Victor Ponta lost his self-control and, with his irrational statements, he offended the entire Hungary," the Hungarian Foreign Minister said in a statement.
Civilized European politicians do not utter such uncontrolled slander.
"His remarks have only one explanation: he has totally lost support in Romania's domestic politics," the Hungarian foreign minister added according to MTI.

In a post on Facebook on Tuesday evening, Prime Minister Victor Ponta said he wanted to draw attention to and sanction the behaviour of high-ranking Hungarian government officials, who in his opinion "are a disgrace to the culture and values of the European Union".
I don't want to respond to the challenges coming from some Hungarian government representatives.

"They are a shame for the culture and values of the European Union; both in their anti-Semitic attitudes and in their treatment of minorities of all kinds and now in the refugee crisis!", Ponta said on Facebook.
The Romanian prime minister added that he is an advocate of rational and sustainable solutions to the refugee crisis, saying that brutality and aggressive laws will not solve the problem.

Barbed wire, aggressive laws, prisons and brutality will definitely not solve the problem - it will only show that in Hungary, in the heart of Europe, political leaders are not any better than those in Syria, Libya or other countries from which refugees are fleeing!

"I believe in solidarity, in rational and sustainable solutions and especially in the superiority of European values - what we are seeing in Hungary these days is in total contradiction with these objectives and values!", the Romanian Prime Minister emphasized.

Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto on Tuesday dismissed as "simple lies" remarks made by Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta about Hungary's handling of the refugee crisis, saying such statements are inappropriate for a 21st century leader, according to MTI.

The Hungarian foreign minister also mentioned on Tuesday that "extremist and false" remarks of the Romanian prime minister are related to the political crisis in Romania and added that Budapest expects an apology from the Romanian side.
Szijjarto referred to a statement made on Monday by Prime Minister Victor Ponta.

What I have always said and I continue to say is that I am against xenophobic speeches, the idea of closing borders, that everyone who comes is a terrorist, that they are medieval idiots and I totally oppose this approach.

If we can receive more, we will receive them, the problem is our logistical capacity to treat those people as people, not as our Hungarian neighbours treat them, with violence and with inhumane conditions.
"I don't agree with that", the Romanian prime minister said at a press conference in Targu-Jiu.

On Tuesday, Peter Szijjarto announced that the Hungarian government had decided to begin preparations on the ground to extend the fence on the border with Romania to face any possible change in the route used by migrants.
Later, Prime Minister Victor Ponta said Hungary's decision to erect a fence on its borders will not solve the refugee problem and "takes Hungary out of Europe."
What is the connection between Osama Bin Laden and the Mecca crane collapse?

Saudi authorities said Saudi construction giant Binladin Group, owned by Osama bin Laden's family, is "partially responsible" for the collapse of a crane at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Friday, which killed 107 people.
According to an investigation committee, the company did not "meet safety standards", the Saudi Press Agency (SPA) reported, BBC reports.
Company executives have been banned from leaving the country pending the outcome of the investigation.
The company will also be barred from new public contracts.
The construction firm is owned by the family of the former leader of the Al-Qaida terrorist network, Osama bin Laden.
The company was founded by Osama bin Laden's father 80 years ago and is currently run by the former terrorist leader's brother Bakr.
The Binladen Group has been working for four years on an expansion of the Grand Mosque to accommodate more pilgrims.
The accident happened Friday evening during a storm, when a crane, likely knocked off balance by strong gusts, toppled over the eastern side of the Grand Mosque in Mecca.
As a result of the accident, 107 people died and almost 400 were injured.
Hagi shuts up detractors
Widely considered to be the greatest Romanian footballer of all time, Gica Hagi was labeled, after retiring from playing, as a weak coach, who could not achieve success in his new position.
After disappointing experiences with the national team, Steaua or Galatasaray, Hagi took over, a year ago, the role of coach at Viitorul Constanta, the team he owns.
After a year of being at the helm of the club, King has proven he is capable of turning a team that was struggling to avoid relegation into a top team.
After one year with Hagi as coach, Viitorul had 16 wins, 11 draws and 11 losses.
The balance is that of a top squad that is battling for European cups.
Things have been looking even better for Viitorul in this season, as the team is now ranked second in Liga 1, with 19 points, one less than leaders Astra Giurgiu.
Future has the best attack in Liga 1, with 20 goals (tied with Astra), more than double that of Steaua.

On the other hand, even if he brought more experienced players to the team, Hagi continued the policy of promoting youngsters and in recent times names like Ianis Hagi or Hodorogea appeared in the starting lineup.

The club policy has made Viitorul a team to watch for foreign teams, so Hagi sold for 1.5 million euros this summer - Ianis Hagi (Fiorentina - 1 million euros) and Alexandru Mitrita (Bari - 500 thousand euros).
Along with Steaua, Viitorul is the only profitable team in Liga 1, according to the data from the Trade Register.
In the refugee crisis, Romania has played so far like a small country.
It's a legitimate strategy, but after that you can't ask to be treated as the seventh country of the EU.
The big countries are coming up with solutions for the whole of the EU, said Cristian Ghinea, a member of the board of the Romanian Centre for European Policies.

In an interview with Ziare.com, Cristian Ghinea said that Europe cannot be converted into a fortress, and pure police methods will not work in this crisis: "Maybe we have doubts about the quality of the values that these people bring."
But there are masses that have been set in motion and we cannot turn back history.
Migration is a reality that we must adapt to as best as we can and adapt them to us.
According to Cristian Ghinea, we are in an extremely emotional moment in which politicians feel the need to show their muscles.

After that, Europeans will not be willing to give up on free movement, but the rules of the Schengen area need to be changed: "Schengen is now like an animal created in another epoch and not adapted to today's situation".
Where are we in the refugee crisis after this JAI council meeting, which, in fact, did not solve anything?
It is clear that the President of the EC, in agreement with Donald Tusk, did not want to force a vote in the Council.
All projections indicated he would have had the necessary votes.
Before the Lisbon Treaty, the JHA operated on the principle of unanimity and any state could block any decision.
Therefore, things have been very little integrated into the field of justice and home affairs.
After Lisbon, the normal procedure applies, where the Commission has the initiative, and the Council approves it with the vote of 55% of states, i.e. 16, representing 65% of the EU population.
The calculations said the votes were there.
But they did not want to go ahead.

Because it's a sensitive issue, there have been reactions even in Germany against Chancellor Merkel's opening policy and some countries didn't want it to appear as EU is sending migrants on our heads.
They have postponed it, but the issue remains because obviously this wave is creating a huge problem for Schengen governance and we will probably see big changes there in the coming period.
So the mandatory quotas were not really eliminated, but the issue was just left to cool down?

Yes, on the other hand, there is talk of greater involvement of the Frontex agency in managing external borders, which means a shift from the individual responsibility of the members who are at the external border of Schengen to the responsibility of the community agencies.
The Greek-Turkish border is also Germany's de facto border with Turkey and the migration wave has exposed the limits of the old Schengen system.
The Dublin principle, under which migrants are the responsibility of the first country where they arrive, might be discarded because it is not sustainable.
If Greece goes down, you can't say forever that it's Greece's problem.
The problem is common.
Because the problem is common, is it possible to solve it without a specific, perhaps even mandatory, mechanism for sharing the reception effort?
No one knows exactly how the quotas will work if they come into force.
But there is still a problem: what do you do with a person who doesn’t want to go to Romania or Portugal, but to Sweden or Germany?
I don't think the European states will start picking up migrants: you go to country X or to country Y.
Likely, there will be some centralised filtering centres in Greece or Turkey, where asylum applications will be processed.
Work is underway on solutions of this kind.
But the problem does not have a simple solution.

There are countries that have decades of experience in trying to integrate migrants, there are countries with no experience, like Romania, where the migrant issue will increase the xenophobic current.
We are talking about millions of people who are in Turkey, in Lebanon, in Jordan, who are living in precarious camps and who have only just started coming to Europe.
An estimate says only 10% have made it, it is hard to cross the Mediterranean in the winter, but we expect next year an even bigger wave.
What do we do with these people?
My prediction is that we're going to get used to this problem, we will not see it as catastrophic from a media standpoint.
You were talking about countries with more or less experience.
Do you think there is any place where the integration of large groups from a non-European culture has really succeeded?
I look at the Maghrebis in France, the Turks in Germany, they are still ghettoized.
I wouldn't go for radical statements.
Certainly their integration is more difficult than in the case of other migration waves, but that doesn't mean they don't integrate at all.
There is a part of the population that is not integrated and that creates major social problems in France, Germany and Britain.
But police tactics won't work.
Creating a fortress Europe is an illusion.
Mechanisms of integration into European societies need to be improved.
There were some mistakes here.
We need to be more demanding.

We should ask these people to learn the language, to try to take up the values, not to remain with one foot in Europe and the other in their country of origin, bringing the rest of their family there even by convenience marriages.
But the immediate problem of these people must be separated from the long-term problem of their integration.
If others have failed in long-term integration it doesn't mean we should watch them drown in the Mediterranean.
Perhaps we have doubts about the quality of the values these people come with.
And if there is an intervention in Syria, which I don't believe will happen, it doesn't mean that the country will be rebuilt overnight and you can send them back.
Until solutions are found, we will see fortresses within Europe.
Borders are being closed, walls are being erected, border controls are being reintroduced into the Schengen area.
Is the European Project in Danger?
The European project as a whole, no. The Schengen area as it was constructed, yes.
It was built quite minimal, and arranging the rules so that the pressure was too great on the countries where these migrants first set foot.
So we move around freely, but each of us has our own problems.
In the face of such a wave, some countries simply cannot cope.
When there are such waves of emotion, politicians want to show that they are doing something, but in the long run nothing much changes.
After the attacks in France we still don't have much tougher anti-terror laws in the EU than we had last year.
It's a wave of public emotion which sets in on both sides.
And it's so unstable from week to week that you can't make decisions based on it.
We have a lot of rhetoric, a lot of tough talk from politicians who are at home under pressure to be macho.
And then you have the dramatic case of the drowned child in Turkey and public opinion is upset.
After the public emotion passes, we will return to the reasons why we created this space, this freedom of movement that is not only for people, but also for goods.
This is the single European real market.
And I don't believe the Europeans will give up on this principle of freedom of movement.
That there will be other rules is another thing.
Schengen is now like an animal that was created in another era and was not adapted for the current situation.
How has Romania played in this crisis so far?
As a small country, which believes if you pull the cap over your eyes and plug your ears, the issue disappears.
In the face of the reality of migrant waves, you can choose to be part of the solution or say it's not your problem in a small country.
We did do that, it is a legitimate strategy, but then you cannot ask to be treated as the seventh country of the EU.
You're not, you don't play at a big country level.
The big countries bring solutions for the entire EU, good or bad, we are not discussing their quality right now.
As Poland did.
On the other hand, the effect of this crisis is that Romanians' appetite for Schengen will decrease very much.
President Iohannis says it is perhaps for the best that we did not enter already.
So we're going from despair to a more pragmatic position, but the objective remains the same.
Of course there is a risk that if Romania and Bulgaria enter Schengen, migrants will see us as an alternative route.
It doesn't mean that we should no longer enter Schengen, but we should be more pragmatic.

Romania will be part of Schengen and Schengen will exist, but it will be transformed, in the sense that the external borders will become a common responsibility, there will be common rules for accepting migrants, common rules for deporting those who don't receive asylum, common rules for countries considered safe.
Ukraine's President says since Russia shifted its attention to Syria, no one has died in Ukraine.
Is there a connection between the two outbreaks, is it a Russian game?
Russia has a behavior of frustrated power.
She believes that being a great power means to confuse the Americans and the Europeans.
In that sense, yes, there is a connection.
Without Putin's military and financial support, the Assad regime would likely have collapsed long ago.
And it was better that it collapsed before its main opponent was the Islamic State.
For about two years it was a battle between the Assad regime and secular and moderate Muslim militias, backed by Gulf states and the West.
Then the Islamic State came up, and now we don't know whether we want the Assad regime to fall.
Russia could complicate matters, but it cannot participate in the solution.
It creates points of instability and chaos that it cannot close down.
But you're a great power only if you have solutions.
Playing offside is just a strategy to win time.
Probably Putin is waiting for offers to be made, to press buttons to solve the situation.
The offers don't come because people are not convinced that he can somehow solve the problems he created.
But I do not agree with the theories that these people are driven by an invisible hand.
Let's not see Putin as stronger than he is.
What button will appear soon
Millions of Facebook users have become accustomed to the Like button, but now the social network is preparing to launch one opposite, a Dislike button.
Mark Zuckerberg, the company's co-founder and chief executive, announced Tuesday on his Facebook page that the button would be available soon, the New York Times reported on its blog.
Zuckerberg said the "Dislike" button would show a more nuanced version of the user's feelings rather than a simple choice.
However, his announcement raises the question of whether Facebook could become a less friendly place.
Zuckerberg said he wanted to avoid situations in which someone posts about a painful experience and someone else might "dislike" it.
Users of the network, which has 1.5 billion active accounts, have long requested the ability to express negative emotions or empathy for something sad.
Mark Zuckerberg also said he was not comfortable with people 'Liking' current events, such as the refugee crisis, or if a family member dies.
"You might not feel comfortable Liking that post," a Facebook representative pointed out.
The new Facebook button hasn't been well received by everyone.
"There is already enough hate on Facebook and social media," commented Atiq Haneef from Afghanistan on the New York Times' Facebook page, where the article was posted.
"I will give the 'Dislike' button the 'Dislike' button," he said.
Roger Anderson, a microbiologist from Atlanta, claimed there is nothing wrong with the button, encouraging people to have different opinions on Facebook.
Debra Aho Williamson, a social media analyst at eMarketer, noted that it is hard to imagine that a single button can convey a complex range of negative emotions.
Moreover, she says, the election campaign in America is approaching, and the "Dislike" button would create a complete disaster.
Only 70 refugees enter Hungary in 24 hours
Hungary only accepted 70 migrants on Tuesday, a tiny fraction of the thousands who have flocked to its southern border with Serbia, government advisor Gyorgy Bakondi said.

Hungary declared a state of emergency Tuesday in two counties along its border with Serbia due to the influx of refugees, closing a main border crossing and announcing it intends to build a fence along its border with Romania, DPA reports.
The measure drew a sharp reaction from Serbia.
They said yesterday that they will seal the border for those that want to cross, but not for those who want to apply for asylum.
"As you can see, this is totally different," Serbian Minister for Refugees, Aleksandar Vulin, said.
Before the new immigration law came into effect, a record number of 5,809 migrants entered Hungary on Sunday, police said Monday.
Also, more than 170,000 migrants from the Middle East and Africa have entered Hungary from Serbia in 2015.
Many avoid being registered and try to make their way to Western Europe, especially Germany.
The "new" county council headquarters is about to collapse.
Two builders in bankruptcy
Massive investments made here in recent years to relocate the institution are at risk of collapse as they have been stalled several times.
Two major contractors who worked on the project have gone bankrupt during the construction process.
The County Council headquarters on Vasile Alecsandri Street will collapse on its own.
More than a year and a half after the consolidation and refunctionalization works were supposed to be completed, the project has not even reached the halfway point.

The latest twist in the building's saga came last week, when the National Council for Solving Complaints (CNSC) rejected a complaint from a company that wanted to take over the contract for the technical project for the remaining works.
The original project was drawn up by Impex Romcatel SA.

After the contractor went bankrupt and construction was halted, negotiations were initiated without a public call for participation with Impex Romcatel, the company being required to update the technical project, and then a new tender for works was organized.

"However, the negotiations have not resulted in a contract, with the CJ deeming the proposed form to be disadvantageous to the institution," summarized Răzvan Timofciuc, CJ's public relations representative.
The CJ's decision to suspend direct negotiations was challenged in court by Impex Romcatel.
The Iasi tribunal forwarded the complaint to the CNSC, which rejected it as untimely.
This does not mean the CJ can start looking for another designer.
Impex Romcatel may appeal the CNSC decision to the Court of Appeal, and only after a final sentence will the search for a new designer be considered.
As a result, consolidation work on the building could resume no sooner than next year.
Our intention is to restart work as soon as possible.
In principle, rebuilding the technical project should not take long, but we must reach the conclusion of a contract.
"We are waiting to see whether CNSC's decision will be appealed or not," Timofciuc said.
Works to consolidate the former police headquarters building started in 2011.
A first contract for the works was terminated in April 2012, after works worth 4.5 million lei had been carried out.
The bidding process was restarted and the contract was awarded to Moldoconstruct SA.
The company went into insolvency and the contract was later cancelled after payments of 1.5 million lei had been made.
The work has been completed by about 50%.
Initially, the works for consolidation, re-functionalization and lofting of the building have been estimated to 7.7 million lei.
"Enough, I'll tell you everything!" - the statement that could incriminate the former head of Cadastre
One of the employees involved in the scandalous case at the Cadastre Office has signed a plea agreement, therefore avoiding prison.
Most likely, his statements will incriminate the other defendants, led by the former head, Narciza Nedelcu
A real estate cadastre and publicity office (OCPI) consultant from Iasi, accused by the National Anticorruption Directorate (DNA) in a corruption case, confessed to the charges.
The plea deal signed by Dumitru Dascalu was registered yesterday at the Iasi Tribunal, with judges deciding to give a verdict in this case on September 29.
Dumitru Daniel Dascalu was charged with continuing intellectual fraud and agreed to serve two years of probation and community service.

As for the facts imputed to Dascălu, prosecutors said that, in his capacity as a consultant to the Land Registry Office, together with other colleagues, "he drew up false minutes of acceptance, regarding the service contracts previously concluded by the O.C.P.I. Iași with the administrators of the companies SC Gauss SRL, SC Grup Cinci SRL, SC Topo Euro Cad SRL, SC Agenția de Ca­dastru și Topografie SRL și PFA Lipșa Ștefan, which attested in a non-real manner that the contracted services were fully made, while these were not made and were not submitted to the O.C.P.I. Iași".

Last week, the former head of the office, Narciza Nedelcu, as well as other former or current employees of the OCPI, were sent to trial in this case, accused of paying for services to the aforementioned companies, although the works were not carried out.
The damage amounts to more than 300,000 lei.
Adventures in Stone Age

According to the President of the Romanian Handball Federation, Alexandru Dedu, Romania can only host a major handball competition in 2024, and preparing the Romanian women's national handball team for the qualification to the Olympic Games costs a fortune.
Alexandru Dedu, President of the Romanian Handball Federation, said yesterday at a press conference that it is a great honor that our country has three teams in the Champions League groups.

As for the Romanian women's national handball team, "the primary objective is to qualify for the Olympics in Rio, but for that we have to get through two tough stages, first the World Championship and then the qualifying tournament," Dedu also said.
We really want to qualify for the Olympic Games.
These are fantastic demands from the technical staff led by Tomas Ryde.
The staff will be comprised of seven or eight people.
He wants a second coach, a doctor, two masseurs, a goalkeepers' coach, a fitness coach and a team manager.
They asked us for some things for our qualification, more specifically physical preparation materials, which we have never heard of.
All of this to get to the Olympics. And I will do everything I can to have them.
This is a massive investment, lots of money.
But that is the way to do performance.
Because right now we're in the Stone Age in terms of preparation.

"The teams we are competing against have this material and have had it for some time," Dedu said, adding that he is trying to obtain the necessary funds for the purchase of these items from the MTS and COSR.
The EHF president also referred to Romania's infrastructure and the possibility for our country to host a major handball competition.
We don't have a room in Bucharest.
It's an infrastructure problem and it's embarrassing to have a European gymnastics championship put into question.
Let's not forget that in other parts of the world Olympic Villages have been built in their entirety in just two years.
Before 1992, Barcelona's current Olympic zone was a garbage dump, but now it has become a beauty spot.
The same was true in London, where the 2012 Olympics were a success in terms of investments.
"In my view, in 2024 we could host a major competition," Dedu said.
He added that the international handball bodies are willing to grant Romania the organization of a major competition.
For me it is a priority to bring major handball competitions to Romania.
Mr. Gațu came with a project, people agreed in principle, but it became clear very soon that the hall will never be built.

I also had discussions with the EHF and I told them we want to do it and that we are capable of organizing and they said they agree and that we should invite them to the first match in the new hall in Bucharest and afterwards we can talk concretely.
"So we have the openness, both at EHF and IHF, but we don't have the infrastructure," the FRH official explained.

The former handball player avoided evaluating the chances of the women's teams CSM Bucharest and HCM Baia Mare to reach the Final Four: "I asked all the coaches to be reserved in the predictions, because if they do not come true they will turn against them".
Clear Path to World Cup
The Romanian rugby players will debut on September 23 against France

Romania's national rugby team captain Mihai Macovei said on Tuesday at a press conference that all team members are ready for the Rugby World Cup matches in England, where they hope to win two games: "We are ready."
Both myself and my colleagues are running at full throttle.
We trained to give our best performance in the four matches.
Everybody will have high expectations because our goal is to win the two matches against Canada and Italy.
All the groups are tough and ours is no exception.
Let's take it easy, first with France and then we will see.
Certainly, if we win against Canada, the match against Italy will be our final.
I can't describe in words the joy of participating in the World Cup, it is the crowning of so many years of hard work.
I want to not disappoint anyone in the rugby family and come back with a good result.
"We want you to be proud that some players, a small family like Romanian rugby, proudly represent the tricolor", Macovei said.
Romania head coach Lynn Howells, in his first World Cup experience as a coach, hopes to make the Romanians proud of their rugby team: "It is a great honour for us to participate in this World Cup".
I am sure the players are prepared to take part in the tournament.
It's an extraordinary experience for me.
For me, it is very important that at every game I make the Romanians proud of the national team.
Romanian Rugby Federation President Haralambie Dumitraș is confident that Romanian players can confirm the progress made in recent years in rugby.
We have a difficult group and we want to confirm the progress made by the national team.
I wish good luck to the athletes and I am sure that we will live up to the event.
"These boys started playing for the Romanian teams at the age of 18-19, so there is cohesion, it's a gang of friends, who have set themselves to achieve a dream," Dumitraș said.

At the Rugby World Cup in England, Romania will compete in Group D and it will play the following matches: against France on September 23 in London; against Ireland on September 27 in London; against Canada on October 6 in Leicester; against Italy on October 11 in Exeter.
The competition kicks off Friday at London's Twickenham Stadium with England versus Fiji in Pool A.
New Japanese Language Courses at Al.I. Cuza University
You can learn about flower arrangements in a vase, painting in ink, as well as a light study of fine arts specific to the Land of the Rising Sun, at the courses organized by Iași students.
The Iasi Japanese Culture Students' Circle organises new Japanese culture courses (ikebana, sumie and fine arts) between October 2015 and June 2016, courses for both beginners and experienced people.
They will be held at the Centre for European Studies of the "Al. I. Cuza" University in Iași and are organized in order to promote Japanese art and culture, both traditional and modern.
There is a single participation fee of 50 lei per person per month.
In addition to art lessons, participants will be able to take part in exhibitions and other cultural activities promoting beauty.
The Japanese culture courses that we have proposed are designed as an invitation for the general public to take the first steps on the road to self-knowledge through art.

"Interested people will be able to learn how to make harmonious floral sculptures (ikebana), how to capture the soul of the surroundings in plastic compositions using the Japanese art of painting in ink (Sumie) or how to express their own individuality and creativity through the multivalent universe of fine arts (graphic, drawing, painting)," said Sorin Mazilu, the teacher of these courses.
The courses are open to everyone who is interested in art, regardless of age or experience.
The registrations will last until September 30th, and those who want more information can call 0742.027.153 or send an e-mail at studenticultura@gmail.com
14 million lei given to Iasi's "St. Spiridon" Hospital at budget revision
What will be purchased with this large amount of money?
The "St. Spiridon" hospital received from the Ministry of Health, as a result of the budget review, about 14 million lei.

The money the medical unit has received to use until the end of the year will be invested in modernizing and setting up clinics, as well as in medical equipment and technology for which the hospital has already begun a public procurement procedure.

Thus, the health unit will be equipped with a new computer tomography, with a new radiology apparatus, with six sets of instruments used for surgical interventions, six intensive care unit beds appropriately equipped, an ophthalmic microscope, and other devices necessary for the medical procedure.
On the other hand, 5 million lei from the money received by the hospital will be directed to the construction and renovation of the "Great Art".
From the revised budget, UPU will receive 500,000 lei for the completion of modernization works on the main section.

"Additionally, in the coming days, we are going to receive the work on the walkway linking the UPU to the cardiology, hepatology and gastroenterology clinics, to ensure decent transport of the patient from the UPU to the neighboring clinics," the hospital manager further explained.
The hospital will soon have the Tătărași Dermatology Clinic in its courtyard, which it will organize as an outpatient clinic, under the same form under which it operates at present.
The clinic will operate in the area where the allergology, hematology and endocrinology departments are located in the outpatient clinic and will have about 30 beds.
Iași is being made fun of by RATP controllers and a brochure.
A Tourist’s Misfortune
A family of tourists from Cluj came to Iași to visit, but the trip ended with a bitter promise.
After the experience we had, neither my wife nor myself want to ever set foot in your city again.
Unintentionally, they had to deal with the erroneous information from the leaflets, with the RAPT controllers' insensitivity and, as a bonus, with a fine "because the law says so".
The couple arrived in Iasi a few days ago, checked into a hotel in the city center and asked for tourist brochures.
They also received a leaflet where the RATP routes were listed.
Armed with these maps, the couple visited Iasi.
But, two days ago, when they were in Copou, they wanted to get to Palas Mall.
Because there was no ticket machine at the station near Copou Park, they relied on the information printed on the leaflet: that they could buy a ticket by SMS.
No one told them that the service no longer exists.
Confident in the leaflet, they boarded a bus and tried to send an SMS according to the instructions on the leaflet.
Unfortunately for them, a team of RATP inspectors showed up.
They said that the service does not exist for 2 years, and that it has been announced in the press that it was canceled.
HOW AM I SUPPOSED TO KNOW what was written in the local press, me coming one evening before to visit the town?
I spoke to the controllers, I explained the situation, they said they don't care, it's none of their business.
His attitude was very defiant.
They said all they could do is give us a single fine instead of two (one for me and one for my wife).
"I paid, I didn't want to waste my day by going to the police station and giving statements there!", says Ovidiu.
The family was fined because of the inaccurate information on the leaflet and because of controllers who "applied the law to the letter".
It is not fair, and I filed a complaint with RATP Iasi to get my money back.
It's not about money, it's not a huge amount, but the idea is that I felt cheated.
Bad luck for the criminals in Vaslui.
They had an accident and are now under preventive detention.
The trial of the seven rapists from Vaslui was moved yesterday to the Court of Appeal in Iași.
A judge in Iași heard the first hearing in a closed session in which seven young men accused of having ridiculed an 18-year-old girl asked to be released.
Before the actual hearing began, one of the judges assigned to the case, Viorel Munteanu, made a request to excuse himself, which was accepted by his colleagues on the bench.

The magistrate was working in the Vaslui County Court until this summer, where he headed the criminal section, he was the one who, on April 9, admitted a complaint submitted by four of the suspects, ordering them to be placed under house arrest.
The case is currently being heard by a panel of judges comprising Maricica Mititelu and Geta Sandu.
Earlier, Judge Dan Anton recused himself from the case on the grounds that his daughter is living in a relationship with one of the rapists' lawyers.
The two judges decided that the Vaslui rapists will remain under arrest.
The youths will remain in custody for at least another 30 days, when judges will reconsider the possibility of releasing them.
The next hearing will take place at the Iasi Court of Appeal on 6 October.
Before reaching the Iasi Court of Appeals, the van that was transporting the rapists from Vaslui was involved in an accident in the Păcurari neighborhood, the car entering Iasi on the ring road.
The Iveco van carrying the seven rapists hit a Volkswagen car that was coming out of Canta Street and the driver tried to turn left.
The van was heading from the Păcurari end.
The car entered Iași on this route because the employees of the Penitentiary Administration preferred the route from Vaslui to Iași through Grajduri, then on the ring road.
They shortened the road by a few kilometers.
Immediately after the crash, the prisoners' escort called in another transport to pick up the detainees.
Shortly after, a car from the Iasi Maximum Security Prison arrived at the scene, which took the seven inmates and transported them to the Court of Appeal.
No one was injured in the accident.
To transfer them to the other van, guards surrounded the back of the vehicles, and the detainees came out quickly, two by two.

"The incident was not reported to the police because the drivers of the two vehicles agreed amicably about the damages that must be paid," said Chief Commissioner Mădălin Țăranu of the Police Inspectorate.
Major migrations
Romania is not and will not be prepared for what is about to come.
But what about Europe?

I will say from the onset, clearly and directly: the some 7,000 refugees that Romania should and must naturalize represent, in itself, an insignificant number, but a huge number in comparison to the capacity of the Romanian state to manage such a project.
For Romania, even the voluntary quota proposed by Bucharest, of about 1,500 people, far exceeds the good intentions of solidarity with the European Union expressed in recent months.
Certainly, if those migrants agree to settle in our communities, the chances of their quick integration into the Romanian society are extraordinarily small.
I am sure they will be the first to lose their patience.
Infested by racketeers and paralyzed by a venal political class, the Romanian state is proving itself impotent in all areas.
The inability to integrate gypsies is just a banal example.

In addition, governments of every color have been unable to absorb EU funds, build roads, kindergartens or modern schools, provide decent medical care, clean up the streets, create decently paid jobs or keep their own young generation at home.
Why would refugees settle in another country from which they are fleeing?
But what is surprising is the hypocrisy with which such a crisis is being treated.
We are first confronted with the belligerent hypocrisy of the powerful states of the EU, which display maximum generosity in sharing their misfortunes with smaller states.

Then comes the cowardly hypocrisy of the Romanians who, although they have millions of relatives scattered all over the world, do not yet accept the other one - of a different language, of a different religion, of a different blood.
Probably for fear that someone would steal their national being.

Finally, there is the hypocrisy of many migrants who, although they invoke the horrors of war as their motive for leaving, do not accept any destination for their exodus other than Germany or the Nordic countries.
But not all refugees are Syrian, and there is no war in Pakistan.
Also, the simplistic way the crisis is analyzed can only be scoffed at.
Some argue that the causes must be addressed, and, betting strictly on the book of political correctness, they call for peace and investment in migrants' home countries.
But in Romania there is peace, and sometimes even a little foreign capital enters the national economy - but this does not prevent tens of thousands of Romanians from leaving the country every year.
Why are they leaving?
In the crisis, the European Union has revealed itself as a rigid, divided and outdated construction.
We deplore the fact that Romania is not capable of inventing a country project, but it seems that the EU does not have a plan for the future, either.
And improvisations and threats don't help anything.
So what's the point of the EU, if the only advantage Romanians enjoyed - the freedom to travel - could be jeopardized because of the waves of refugees flooding the borders?
At some point the war in Syria will end.
But not the migrant crisis.
In the coming decades, overpopulation, poverty, climate change, resource depletion, etc. will drive millions of desperate migrants, mostly from Asia and especially Africa, toward a better life.
With such politicians, Romania will never be prepared for what is to come.
7,000 euros per year to rent the Pogor Club.
Destination, Practically Imposed
The concession bid is for a 10-year period.
After 7 years in which it remained closed, the club in the yard of the Romanian Literature Museum is offered for concession by the County Council for a period of 10 years.
The structure has a usable surface of 134 square metres, on two levels of basements.
CJ accepts that the building will be used only for literary cafes, bookstores or other cultural activities.
The building was valued at 68,300 euros and the starting bid was set at 6,830 euros per year, with a bidding increment of 25 euros.
The concessionaire will be required to operate the building continuously and permanently and cover all the costs of the building's reconstruction according to a technical project to be drawn up.

"The Pogor Club building is in an advanced state of degradation due to the fact that during the period when this space was occupied by the catering unit and even after its evacuation, no current repair and maintenance works were carried out, as are necessary during the exploitation of a building," the documentation relevant to the tender procedure states.
Bids for the club's concession are expected by September 18.
Two brothers from Tomești have swallowed sleeping pills.
They were taken to hospital
Two children from Tomești, brothers aged 9 and 11, swallowed several Diazepam pills.
They found the pills in the house and they took them out of curiosity.
Their mother was undergoing treatment, and the medicines were not hidden.
The children were rushed to the Sfânta Maria Hospital in Iași.
They are in stable condition, the doctors say.
EXCLUSIVE: A heart-breaking meeting.
At 20 years old, she received a courageous gift: her biological parents

Lost in hospital in unclear circumstances at the beginning of the 90s, when she was only 2 months old, small, ill and helpless, she was then adopted by a wealthy family from Italy, in the same year when adoption was vaguely regulated, a young woman from Iasi, now a beautiful blonde girl, has reunited in Iasi with her biological parents from a village of the region, after almost two decades in which no one knew anything about each other.

Crina is about to turn 20 years old, and her adoptive parents in Palermo decided to give their beloved daughter an amazing and courageous gift: a visit to Romania, in Iasi, to find out more about her unclear past.
The Iași Newspaper, which has assisted in searching for the family of origin after a few extremely vague clues, witnessed these meetings which basically break your heart.
The reporters' account, the emotions of the moment, the statements of those involved, their reactions are truly moving and overwhelming.
Crina's story begins 20 years ago in the Iasi village of Ruginoasa, when she was only two months old.
At that time, due to a health problem, the girl had to be admitted to hospital in the city.
At home there began to be disagreements between parents, and the mother was forced to leave home.
He decided to keep the child and send me away.
He stopped the girl, and since then we haven't heard anything.
"When I found out she was in hospital, it was too late," Alina, the girl's biological mother, recalls sadly.
Crina was hospitalized with her grandmother at the municipal hospital in Pascani, while the girl's father, Costica Balcan, left for work in Alexandria, Teleorman County.
Their lives would part forever.
They could not find Crina at the hospital
After Crina was hospitalised, her father went to work in another town, and he returned after six months.
Meanwhile, the girl was taken to the hospital in Iași, and when her father returned, he could not find her.
I think it was almost nine months that the girl was in hospital.
"She must have thought she was abandoned," a granddaughter of the family says.
Due to financial difficulties, the grandmother could not accompany Crina to Iasi, and the girl remained in the care of the doctors.

As nobody had shown interest in the child's fate during that time, she was taken over by the General Directorate for Social Assistance and Child Protection in Iasi, which then entrusted her to the Bucium Placement Center.
Those were the years when abandonment and adoption were more loosely regulated in Romania than they are today.
The Bucium Center was found by the Italian Salvadore and his wife, a couple from Palermo who wanted to have their child but failed.
They fell in love with the blonde Crina, and after some time she would move permanently with them to Italy.
The child had already reached nearly two years old, the time it took to complete the adoption process.
When I saw Crina, I felt like she was our daughter.
"As if my wife gave her life," says Salvadore, the adoptive father, smiling as he holds the frail girl's hand in his.
Back home, Crina's parents, Alina and Costică, continued the search separately, each in their own way.
The father asked the authorities in Ruginoasa, but got no answer as to where his child might be.
Police then told them that it was possible she was dead, but in Iasi, the parents found out what had really happened to their daughter.
When I looked for her here, they told me at the Tribunal that she had gone to Italy, to Palermo.
And I didn't have any conditions to look for it.
We prayed to God that everything will be alright.
I've thought about her all those years, but there was no way to go and find her.
"It's difficult," Crina's biological mother tells us with tears in her eyes.
But even though the years have gone by, parents in Ruginoasa have not been forgotten.
In Italy, Salvadore and his wife explained to the girl where she came from and that her past is linked to Romania.
I was young when I found out.
I guess I was five or six years old.
I reacted like a child. I was curious.
"I wanted to meet my parents from Romania," Crina said enthusiastically.
And her dream was going to come true.

In March this year, chief inspector Romica Ichim, director of the Iasi Regional Centre for Drug Abuse Prevention, Assessment and Counselling, was contacted by an acquaintance in Italy, who explained Salvadore's desire to find Crina's biological family.
And the search started with just one name.
