Following the request we had from our partners in Italy, we began the first steps.
I had only one name, Costica Balcan, and a village, Ruginoasa.
Shortly thereafter I had activity with the municipality there, and I was able to ask if there was the given name in the area.
They gave me a few hints, but the person they found was not the one they were looking for.
"It took us about a month to find the girl's biological father", chief inspector Romica Ichim explained.
It took over three months for the authorities to find Costica and Alina, especially as they each had a residence in a different place.
We started the procedure in March and we finalized the identification of the biological parents and the discussions in June-July.
"We decided that the first meeting should take place in September," Romica Ichim said.
This past weekend, Alina and Costică saw their lost daughter for the first time in 20 years in the Iași hospital hallway.
The father, emotional, could barely contain his tears and his hands trembled incessantly.
He barely exchanged a few words with those around him.
A week before the meeting, he could hardly sleep.
He was trembling, overwhelmed with emotion.
"It's something to see your child after so many years," says a granddaughter, who also came with Costică from Ruginoasa.
Crina's Meeting with Her Biological Mother and Brother

In the discussions with his daughter, who is going to study at a well-rated university in Italy, Costică Balcan told her, among other things, that if she ever wanted to return to him, in the village, she should come in peace: he can give her some sheep, goats, to find a boy from the village and to build up a household.
The mother is also emotional, crying, and she can hardly believe that something like this could happen to her.
I am very excited.
I did not believe it could happen.
I have seen these cases on TV, I have thought about these things for years, I have hoped, but I have not thought that I could be in such a situation.
There are very strong emotions.
If I could be forgiven.
I hope we will visit each other in the future.
"I hope we can keep in touch," Alina, Crina's mother, says with tears running down her cheeks as she clutches a tissue in her hand.
He hides his tears of joy, because soon he will see his daughter after so much bitterness.
On the other hand, Crina, who will turn 20 this month, tries to calm herself down like an emotional child.
She does not know what to expect, but she has a vague idea about her biological parents.
He thinks they are young, but now before the meeting, he tries to gather his thoughts, because he has a lot to say, but nothing to reproach.
My parents are two mothers and two fathers.
But my parents are the ones who raised me.
It'll be a beautiful meeting, a wonderful experience.
"I hope I have good memories of them, because now there are so many things to say," Crina confesses.
A First Family Reunion in Iasi
At Unirii Square, under the early autumn skies, the family from Ruginoasa reunites its destiny with their daughter from Palermo.
Crina is now 20, she's finishing high school, following the Italian school model, but she can start a new chapter with Alina and Costica, her biological parents.
They are no longer separated by borders or countries, but by a single barrier: language.
Over which, with the help of a translator, an Italian bar owner in the center of Iași passed easily.
Those who made this meeting possible said it was the first event of its kind, and that they would do it again if the opportunity arose.
It is the first event of its kind and I am happy that it is a success.
We, at the Centre, have different activities, and most of the time we are associated as an institution that deals only with consumers, people who are dependent on drugs.
But we are trying to give something good back to society.

"If I am asked again to participate in such an event, I will do so with great pleasure," says smiling Romică Ichim, the director of the Iași Regional Center for Prevention, Evaluation, and Drug Counseling.
Behind them, the Balcan family, with Crina in the middle, walks away telling stories.
It makes sense: they have a lot to tell each other.
Armed truce at the PSD headquarters yesterday.
Everyone is catching their breath
The factions within PSD's Iasi branch have reached an armistice with guns in hand.
After several rounds of talks, held from Friday to Sunday, the first and most tense one, PSD leaders agreed to temporarily suspend hostilities.
Pressured by the party's executive president, Liviu Dragnea, to present a united front, the Social Democrats in Iaşi will send him a full list of potential candidates for party positions.
Far from being over, the internal war in the party appears to have taken only a pause to allow combatants to catch their breath.
Dragnea did not give an ultimatum.
He delivered a very simple, very timely message under the current circumstances: try to find a solution that doesn't put the party at risk.
On October 3rd we have elections in the party.
All positions will be made available to those who want them.
“Until then, we will remain in the existing structure,” interim mayor Mihai Chirica said.
The two days of discussions over the weekend led only to the conclusion that nothing concrete was settled.
At the elections in October, a fierce competition is expected for the position of president of the county branch of the PSD.

The shortlist of potential candidates for the party's top position in Iasi includes State Secretary Maricel Popa, Senator Florin Constantinescu, Senator Sorin Lazăr, County Councilor Vasile Câtea, and Interim County Council President Victorel Lupu.
The list might also include the mayor of Schitu Duca, Mihai Mihalache.

A possible alternative is the candidacy of PSD leader of the county council Cristian Stanciu, if Lupu does not register for the race, sources within the party said that he is not interested in the position.
The only name that has not been mentioned by any of the participants in the negotiations over the past few days is that of the former leader of the party's local branch, Mayor Gheorghe Nichita.
The list of candidates is open.
Under the rules, including on election day, candidacies can be filed, and no one would be surprised if that happened.

"It is important that we stay united and we will remain united even after October 3, when we will have a new Executive Bureau, a new County Permanent Bureau and all the new leadership structures," Câtea said.
Until the internal elections are organized, the county branch of the PSD will be led by Victorel Lupu, a close ally of Nichita and Stanciu.

Lupu is, however, on leave until September 29, with the party's preparations for the elections to be carried out by the executive secretary of the branch, county councillor Mihail Popescu, who is on bad terms with the Nichita camp.
Contacted by phone, Cristian Stanciu described the discussions of the past few days as leading to "a partial consensus".
There is widespread willingness to keep balance and unity in the party.
A partial consensus has been reached, supporting a unified team to deal with the county.
"On the other hand, there are several versions concerning the intentions to run for the PSD presidency in Iasi, and the list remains open", Stanciu commented.
A Iași judge rejected a case involving rapists from Vaslui on the grounds of cohabitation
The seven young men from Vaslui county, who were convicted of rape, will arrive today at the Court of Appeal in Iasi.

The Vaslui convicts sentenced to prison terms between 5 years and 8 months and 8 years and 4 months will present arguments today in favor of their release, after the trial court, Vaslui Court, decided to put them behind bars immediately after pronouncing the sentence.
The case was filed with the appeals court last week, with Judge Dan Anton filing a request for recusal, which was granted by his colleagues.
Anton cited the fact that one of the defendants' lawyers, Bogdan Luca, is the partner of his daughter, lawyer Dana Anton.
Luca is defending Silviu Ovidiu Burada, who received the highest sentence in this case.
How the judge justified the sentence
The Vaslui judge who convicted the seven youths last week issued a ruling explaining his decision.
In his reasoning, the judge talked about the defiant reaction of the defendants and their supporters, saying such an attitude creates a strong sense of indignation among the public.

"The court acknowledges that, after the preventive measure of judicial control, a restrictive but not restrictive measure of freedom, under the impact of the behavior of the defendants, their families and local supporters, a strong feeling of indignation was felt at the local and national community level regarding the fact that persons accused of serious crimes are tried under a less restrictive measure," the Vaslui Court of Justice said.
The magistrates also dismissed the main defense of the seven defendants who had argued during the trial that the girl they raped was not a "church door".

"The court underlines that the victim's moral qualities are irrelevant, an aspect that the defendants sought to emphasize in their defenses, since the physical and sexual freedom of a person cannot be violated under any pretext," the reasoning reads.
Corbyn, Brexit and the future of Europe
Because of economic and demographic reasons, the prosperity enjoyed in the last decades cannot go on in the same way in the coming years.
Until Saturday, not many people in Romania probably knew who Jeremy Corbyn was.
Even now, as he becomes the new leader of the British Labour Party, many people wonder how the choice of a politician who, after all, is not in a decision-making position can affect us.
Jeremy Corbyn is Labour's most left-wing leader since the Second World War.

An avowed Marxist, anti-monarchist (he once asked then prime minister Tony Blair to move the Royal Family out of Buckingham Palace), a fierce anti-American and a supporter of Vladimir Putin (he was regularly invited to comment on political events by the Russian TV channel Russia Today), and of the terrorist movements Hezbollah and Hamas, he wants Britain to give up its nuclear weapons and leave NATO and the EU.
For Corbyn, who at the time called the killing of Osama bin Laden a tragedy, ISIS is almost preferable to the United States.
Like all populist demagogues, Corbyn, of course, has miraculous anti-austerity solutions.
Things like the ones Tsipras was saying and promising in Greece until the moment he faced real life and economic realities.
The Labour leader's economic program includes, among other things, massive re-nationalisations and printing money to fund development projects and pay for very generous social benefits.
Of course, some may ask why the printing money solution is not universally adopted across the globe, we would then have global prosperity!, but who cares about such details.

Sure, we can tax bankers to the hilt, who have become a kind of a left-wing enemy of sorts, but as we've seen time and again in the past, not just in the former communist states or in Ecuador or Venezuela, but also in France during the beginning of Mitterand and Hollande's mandates.
The extra money is quickly swallowed up by the generous, unfunded promises made by populist demagogues.
As Margaret Thatcher once observed, "The problem with socialism is that eventually you run out of other people's money".
Few people believe Jeremy Corbyn has any chance of becoming prime minister.
In the early 1980s, another left-wing radical, Michael Foot, who was not as extreme in his views as the newly elected party leader, failed miserably in the elections.
And there was still a working class in Britain, in the classic sense of the word - a relatively substantial and structured working class.
And the unions were much more influential than they are now.

In the new industrial landscape, where services dominate the workforce and widespread automation has left industry needing massive amounts of highly skilled labour, Mr. Corbyn's rhetoric has limited appeal.
But even in opposition, he can influence important developments that can directly affect us.
In its latest issue, Financial Times argues that Corbyn's election increases the chances of Brexit, that is Britain's exit from the EU.
The new Labour leader has been a consistent opponent of Britain's membership in the European Union.
In the eyes of the radical left, Brussels is the agent of international capitalism and a promoter of globalization that has imposed austerity on the poor.

When you combine such ideas with those expressed by the radical right, with anti-immigration rhetoric, and look at the refugee crisis that is shaking the foundations of the EU, you get an explosive mixture.
And not only for Britain.

But if Britons decide in a referendum due by 2017 to leave the EU, the loss of symbolic capital for the entire European project and the deep fissures opened within it by the Eurozone crisis and now the refugee crisis, between North and South, east and West, leave room for the most worrying scenarios.
All the more so because for a whole series of member states, London was a counterweight to the Franco-German axis (in which in any case Berlin is increasingly becoming the dominant actor).
It is true that the British business community, the City, are strong advocates for the country to remain in the EU.
But today's Europe is not the Europe of the past.
There is a lot of resentment, which is increasing in intensity even in these weeks.

The problem is that Brussels, we had a recent example in the speech of Jean-Claude Juncker, is increasingly taking major decisions over the heads of the majority of member states, consulting only a few European powers, mainly Germany.
This is happening at a time when support for anti-system, anti-immigration and Eurosceptic parties is growing across the continent.
In other words, the negative emotional climate has reached higher levels than ever before.
This is the conclusion the Financial Times reaches when evaluating the chances of Brexit.
The pro-EU option is based on a cold calculation that stems from national interest.
If voters take a cerebral decision, then Britain will remain in the EU.
But Corbyn's victory reminds us of the power of emotion in contemporary politics.
But Eastern Europe can be significantly affected by such major developments.

Especially if, as expected, we will see a more pronounced integration of the Eurozone, which will push most of the region's states to the periphery of both interest and decision-making processes in Europe.
Corbyn, Tsipras and Syriza in Greece, Podemos in Spain, even Bernie Sanders in the United States are feeding off populist rhetoric born of accumulated frustrations in Western societies.
For economic and demographic reasons, the prosperity that the country enjoyed over the past decades, the generous social benefits can no longer continue in the same way in the coming years.

Under the dual pressure of the Eurozone crisis and the immigration crisis, both caused by hasty decisions that took into account only the integrationist political ambitions, not the ability and willingness of the peoples and governments of Europe to respond to such challenges, the turbulence on the continent, the internal tensions within the EU will increase in intensity and can affect majorly the situation in Romania.
And it's hard to exclude anything from the point of view of possible scenarios.
The question is whether our main political leaders are capable of dealing with such complicated situations.
Constantin Brâncuși, the peasant god.
Rockefeller: "How can I help you?"
Brancusi: "Clean up the workshop!"
The great sculptor had a great dream: to be somebody, to become famous, to be heard about all over the world.
But behind his fame lies something almost forgotten today, when we are delivered millions of success stories, recipes for success in life.
That something has a name.
It is called "truda".
What should we write about Constantin Brâncuși?
What else is there to say, really?
His image has appeared on banknotes.
And recently, a well-known Romanian bank hired an actor to play him in an advertisement.
Brancusi has been producing and delivering money for almost 60 years after his death.
In Romania there are hundreds of streets and boulevards that bear his name.
In fact, the author of this text lives on one of the streets.
And when she goes out with the child, she hears the following instructions: "We're going to the park, to Brâncuși".
The country is littered with his statues.
There are few Romanian personalities whose works are known by so many people, from children to elderly.
Brancusi's capacity for infiltration is enormous.
The communists have not succeeded in eradicating him from the Romanian memory and culture.
His quotes are now all over the internet, receiving hundreds of thousands of likes and shares.
And then, again, what else is there to say, to write about this man?
Seen from the pile of books and articles that seek to reconstruct his fate, Brancusi's life seems almost fantastic, totally improbable.
You know, those who tell you that if you were not lucky enough to be born in a big city and in a relatively well-off family, your chances of success in life are almost nil.
Brancusi's life is a perfect counter-example.
And that, perhaps, is a key.
Perhaps this is where the following text should begin.
With a sentence, however despicable it may be.
Forget the stupid success stories that are delivered to you daily in newspapers and on TV.
Take a good look at this man.
Do you want to know how he succeeded in life, how, today, the whole world has heard of him?
It's simple.
He worked hard all his life to become somebody.
It did.
Constantin Brâncuși was born on February 19, 1876 in Hobița, a small village in the commune of Peștișani, in the Gorj County, at the foot of the Carpathian Mountains.
He is the fifth child of Maria and Radu Nicolae Brâncuși.
Although he came from a wealthy peasant family, Brancusi led a modest life from which he would draw the references that would later guide his artistic vision.
Recalling his childhood and the places where he grew up, the artist would confess in a meeting with Petre Țuțea, in Paris in 1933: "Back then life was beautiful and harmonious".
For millennia, people led a happy patriarchal life.
Everything went on peacefully from one season to another.
And do you know why things changed?
The civilization of the great city has reached us.
Brancusi's childhood was far from idyllic.
One event in these early years is extremely suggestive of the combination of purity and violence that characterized the future sculptor's years spent in his native locality.
The moment is recounted in the book "Brâncuși. A Biography", written by Alexandru Buican.
In 1879, Constantin Brâncuși was 3 years old.
In the fall of that year, while keeping an eye on those who were sampling the liquid, to see if the process was going as it should, Brancusi caught a moment of general inattention.
He fills his palms with brandy and drinks it in one gulp.
He falls asleep almost instantly.
The first people notice it only after several minutes.
The mother enters into panic, then into hysteria, believing that her son had died.
In the evening, when the father, Radu, returns home from the vineyard accompanied by musicians, he sees from a distance the desperate signs of those who await him anxiously.
The party immediately turns into mourning.
The father is already thinking about the funeral.
Somebody, however, thinks it is right to call her Baba Brândușa, witch and servant of Brâncusi.
Brândușa checks the child's breathing, then places some horse manure under his nose.
The child sneezes loudly.
The world applauds.
While the boy sleeps off his drunkenness, the party continues with even greater force.
The next day the father and the son meet in the orchard.
Radu Brancusi makes Constantin gather some willow twigs and bring them to him.
The father puts his child upside down and with the sticks brought by the boy, he beats him to keep in mind.
And, while he feels the sting of the blows, little Brancusi has the revelation that the world can be seen from a different perspective and that things around him can appear upside down.
Especially the fact that the sun is in a different position than the one he knows makes him wonder, as he would confess in his old age, if maybe the star itself was involved in his confusion.
Had the sun been as troubled as his father by what had happened to him?
The city is not functioning right now.
A lawmaker calls on politicians to remember those who voted for them.
Independent MP Viorel Blajut has appealed to the PSD and PNL to stop the internal fighting and reorient their agenda towards the electorate.
What we see in our political scene now is a great divide and that's it.
I haven't seen anything from the USL project from 2012 that has continued.
No highway, no regional emergency hospital, just politicians fighting over possible locations in accordance with real estate interests.
Let's put politics aside for a moment, get together and talk.
Currently, the city is not functioning.
"If you are busy with an internal war, you don't have time for the people who elected you," Blajut said.

He said the current political class has disappointed the Iasi electorate, and the consequence will be a low turnout in the upcoming local elections, around 30%, representing the loyal electorate of the parties.
The MP also thinks that voters will turn to traditional parties, expressing reservation towards new political initiatives, such as the "For Iaşi" party, which will be launched today.
Local parties have very little chance and will only split the right-wing vote, not that of the PSD.
Such parties rely on civic activists, who usually tend to be right-wing.
"The right is becoming even more fragmented, which is not good for anyone, not even for the PSD," Blajut said.
He said he was not interested in running for office in the upcoming local elections, denying rumors that he would run for mayor.
I have already said that I do not want to run for any local office.
I am still thinking about whether I will continue as a deputy for the next term.
I tried to appeal to unity for Iasi during the discussions in the hallways, with the other parliamentarians, and I was accused of wanting to build up my image.
I don't want to, but we can't continue like this.

"If people voted for us, it doesn't mean they are stupid to vote for us again if they see nothing," said Blajut, who argued that the main reason why the electorate is no longer interested in politics is the hypocrisy of elected officials.
A colleague from Tătărași said he doesn't have enough money and has to go by bus.
Let's not be hypocrites.
That is not a small amount of money.
Sometimes I am ashamed to pick up money from the cashier.
At the end of my term I will make a report on all the expenses I have incurred, apart from the salaries of the employees of the cabinet and its maintenance.
I managed to raise 30,000 lei in a month, with all the transportation, accommodation and other expenses accounted for.
"For a parliamentarian to say he does not get enough money is pure hypocrisy," Blăjuț concluded.
